By March 1, 1976, Wozniak completed the machine and took it to a [Homebrew Computer Club](/wiki/Homebrew_Computer_Club "Homebrew Computer Club") meeting to show it off.[[16]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20045-16) When Jobs saw Wozniak's computer, which later became the [Apple I](/wiki/Apple_I "Apple I"), he was immediately interested in its commercial potential.[[17]](#cite_note-17) Initially, Wozniak intended to share schematics of the machine for free, but Jobs insisted that they should instead build and sell bare [printed circuit boards](/wiki/Printed_circuit_board "Printed circuit board") for the computer.[[18]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201562-18) Wozniak originally offered the design to [Hewlett-Packard](/wiki/Hewlett-Packard "Hewlett-Packard") (HP), where he worked at the time, but was denied by the company on five occasions.[[19]](#cite_note-AI-19) Jobs eventually convinced Wozniak to go into business together and start a new company of their own.[[20]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20045–6-20) In order to raise the money they needed to produce the first batch of printed circuit boards, Jobs sold his [Volkswagen Type 2](/wiki/Volkswagen_Type_2 "Volkswagen Type 2") [minibus](/wiki/Minibus "Minibus") for $1,500, and Wozniak his [HP-65](/wiki/HP-65 "HP-65") [programmable calculator](/wiki/Programmable_calculator "Programmable calculator") for $500.[[18]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201562-18)[[16]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20045-16)[[21]](#cite_note-21)[[22]](#cite_note-22)

### Apple I and company formation

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Apple I and company formation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Apple_Garage.jpg/250px-Apple_Garage.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Garage.jpg)

[Steve Jobs](/wiki/Steve_Jobs "Steve Jobs")' parents' home on Crist Drive in [Los Altos, California](/wiki/Los_Altos,_California "Los Altos, California"), where Apple started its operation.[[23]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048-23) Initial work took place in his bedroom and later moved to the home's garage.[[15]](#cite_note-Apple_Confidential-15)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Apple_1_Woz_1976_at_CHM.agr_cropped.jpg/250px-Apple_1_Woz_1976_at_CHM.agr_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_1_Woz_1976_at_CHM.agr_cropped.jpg)

Wozniak's [Apple I](/wiki/Apple_I "Apple I") design was sold as an assembled circuit board and without any sort of covering. Users only needed to supply a TV and a keyboard.



[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple_first_logo.png/250px-Apple_first_logo.png)](/wiki/File:Apple_first_logo.png)

The first [Apple logo](/wiki/Apple_logo "Apple logo"), drawn by [Ronald Wayne](/wiki/Ronald_Wayne "Ronald Wayne"), depicts [Isaac Newton](/wiki/Isaac_Newton "Isaac Newton") under an apple tree.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg/250px-Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Apple_Computer_Logo_rainbow.svg)

Created by [Rob Janoff](/wiki/Rob_Janoff "Rob Janoff") in 1977, the Apple logo with the rainbow scheme was used from April of that year[[24]](#cite_note-24) until August 26, 1999.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

On April 1, 1976, Apple Computer Company was founded by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and [Ronald Wayne](/wiki/Ronald_Wayne "Ronald Wayne").[[25]](#cite_note-25)[[20]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20045–6-20) The company was registered as a California [business partnership](/wiki/Business_partnership "Business partnership").[[26]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201639-26)
Wayne, who worked at [Atari, Inc.](/wiki/Atari,_Inc. "Atari, Inc.") as a chief draftsman, became a co-founder in return for a 10% stake.[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwaine2014336–338-27)[[20]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20045–6-20)[[2]](#cite_note-partnership-2) Wayne was gun-shy due to the failure of his own venture four years earlier. On April 12, less than two weeks after the company's formation, Wayne left Apple, selling his 10% share back to the two Steves for $800.[[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201565–66-28)[[29]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8-29)

According to Wozniak, Jobs proposed the name “Apple Computer” when he had just come back from [Robert Friedland](/wiki/Robert_Friedland "Robert Friedland")'s All-One Farm in Oregon.[[29]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8-29) Jobs told [Walter Isaacson](/wiki/Walter_Isaacson "Walter Isaacson") that he was "on one of my fruitarian diets," when he conceived of the name and thought "it sounded fun, spirited and not intimidating ... plus, it would get us ahead of Atari in the phone book."[[30]](#cite_note-30)

The two Steves made a last trip to the Homebrew Computer Club and demonstrated the [Apple I](/wiki/Apple_I "Apple I") (AKA: The Apple Computer).[[31]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201639–40-31) [Paul Terrell](/wiki/Paul_Terrell "Paul Terrell"), who operated the computer store chain [Byte Shop](/wiki/Byte_Shop "Byte Shop"), was impressed,[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwaine2014336–338-27) and gave the two Steves his card, asking them to keep in touch.[[32]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201566-32) The next day, Jobs visited Terrell at the [Mountain View](/wiki/Mountain_View,_California "Mountain View, California") Byte Shop store, and tried to sell him the bare circuit boards for the Apple I.[[29]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20046–8-29) Terrell said he was only interested in purchasing the machine fully assembled, and that he would order 50 assembled computers and pay US$500 each on delivery (equivalent to $2,800 in 2024).[[33]](#cite_note-iCon-p35-33)[[34]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20047-34)[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwaine2014336–338-27) Jobs took the purchase order from the Byte Shop to national electronic parts distributor Cramer Electronics, and ordered the components needed. When asked by the credit manager how he would pay for the parts, Jobs replied, "I have this purchase order from the Byte Shop chain of computer stores for 50 of my computers and the payment terms are [COD](/wiki/Cash_on_delivery "Cash on delivery"). If you give me the parts on net 30-day terms I can build and deliver the computers in that time frame, collect my money from Terrell at the Byte Shop and pay you."[[35]](#cite_note-35)[[36]](#cite_note-wozniak198412-36)

To verify the purchase order, the credit manager called Paul Terrell, who assured him if the computers showed up, Jobs would have more than enough money for the parts order. The two Steves and their small crew spent day and night building and testing the computers, and delivered to Terrell on time. Terrell was surprised to receive a batch of assembled circuit boards, as he had expected complete computers with a case, monitor and keyboard.[[37]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201567–68-37)[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38) Nonetheless, he kept his word and paid the two Steves the money promised.[[39]](#cite_note-VintageNews-39)[[37]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201567–68-37)[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38)[[40]](#cite_note-iCon-p36-40)

The Apple I went on sale in July 1976 as an assembled circuit board with a retail price of $666.66.[[41]](#cite_note-41)[[42]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20047–8-42)[[43]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201569–70-43) Wozniak later said he had had no idea about the relation between the number and the [mark of the beast](/wiki/Mark_of_the_beast "Mark of the beast"), and that he came up with the price because he liked repeating digits.[[39]](#cite_note-VintageNews-39) About 200 units of the Apple I were eventually sold.[[44]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200414-44)

The Apple I computer had some notable features, including the use of a [TV](/wiki/Television "Television") display, whereas many machines had no display at all. This was not like the displays of later machines; the text was displayed at 60 characters per second – still faster than the teleprinters of contemporary machines of that era. The machine had [bootstrap](/wiki/Booting "Booting") code on [ROM](/wiki/Read-only_memory "Read-only memory"), making it easier to start up. At the insistence of Paul Terrell, Wozniak designed a cassette interface for loading and saving programs, at the then-rapid pace of 1200 bit/s. The simple machine was a masterpiece of design using far fewer parts than anything in its class, and earned Wozniak his reputation as a designer.

Jobs looked for investments to expand the business,[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38) but banks were reluctant to lend him money; the idea of a computer for ordinary people seemed absurd at the time. In August 1976, Jobs approached his former boss at Atari, [Nolan Bushnell](/wiki/Nolan_Bushnell "Nolan Bushnell"), who recommended that he meet with [Don Valentine](/wiki/Don_Valentine "Don Valentine"), the founder of [Sequoia Capital](/wiki/Sequoia_Capital "Sequoia Capital").[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38) Valentine was not interested in funding Apple, but in turn introduced Jobs to [Mike Markkula](/wiki/Mike_Markkula "Mike Markkula"), a millionaire who had worked under him at [Fairchild Semiconductor](/wiki/Fairchild_Semiconductor "Fairchild Semiconductor").[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38) Markkula saw great potential in the two Steves, and became an [angel investor](/wiki/Angel_investor "Angel investor") of their company.[[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201645–47-45) He invested $92,000 in Apple out of his own property while securing a $250,000 (equivalent to $1,380,000 in 2024) line of credit from Bank of America.[[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201645–47-45)[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38) In return, Markkula received a one-third stake in Apple.[[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201645–47-45) Apple Computer, Inc. was incorporated on January 3, 1977.[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38) The new corporation bought out the partnership the two Steves had formed nine months earlier.[[46]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201577–78-46)

In February 1977, Markkula recruited [Michael Scott](/wiki/Michael_Scott_(Apple) "Michael Scott (Apple)") from [National Semiconductor](/wiki/National_Semiconductor "National Semiconductor") to serve as the first president and CEO of Apple Computer, as the two Steves were both insufficiently experienced and he was not interested in taking that position himself.[[47]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200411-47)[[48]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201648–50-48)
That same month, Wozniak resigned from his job at [Hewlett-Packard](/wiki/Hewlett-Packard "Hewlett-Packard") to work full-time for Apple.[[46]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201577–78-46)[[49]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200421-49)

### Apple II

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Apple II")]

Main article: [Apple II (original)](/wiki/Apple_II_(original) "Apple II (original)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Apple_II_Plus_cropped.jpg/250px-Apple_II_Plus_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_II_Plus_cropped.jpg)

[Apple II Plus](/wiki/Apple_II_Plus "Apple II Plus"), designed primarily by Wozniak

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Disk_II.jpg/250px-Disk_II.jpg)](/wiki/File:Disk_II.jpg)

[Disk II](/wiki/Disk_II "Disk II"), also designed by Wozniak

Almost as soon as Apple had started selling its first computers, Wozniak moved on from the Apple I and began designing a greatly improved computer: the [Apple II](/wiki/Apple_II_(original) "Apple II (original)").[[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201645–47-45) Wozniak completed a working prototype of the new machine by August 1976.[[38]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer20048–10-38)[[50]](#cite_note-50) The two Steves presented the Apple II computer to the public at the first [West Coast Computer Faire](/wiki/West_Coast_Computer_Faire "West Coast Computer Faire") on April 16 and 17, 1977. On the first day of the exhibition, Jobs introduced the Apple II to a Japanese chemist named Toshio Mizushima, who became the first authorized Apple dealer in Japan. In the May 1977 issue of [*Byte*](/wiki/Byte_(magazine) "Byte (magazine)"), Wozniak said of the Apple II design, "To me, a personal computer should be small, reliable, convenient to use, and inexpensive."[[51]](#cite_note-wozniak197705-51)

The Apple II went on sale on June 10, 1977, with a retail price of $1,298.[[52]](#cite_note-52) The computer's main internal difference from its predecessor was a completely redesigned TV interface, which held the display in memory. Now not only useful for simple text display, the Apple II included graphics and, eventually, color. During the development of the Apple II, Jobs pressed for a well-designed plastic case and built-in keyboard, with the idea that the machine should be fully packaged and ready to run out of the box.[[53]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201571–74-53) This was almost the case for the Apple I computers, but one still needed to plug various parts together and type in the code to run BASIC. Jobs wanted the Apple II case to be "simple and elegant", and hired an industrial designer named [Jerry Manock](/wiki/Jerry_Manock "Jerry Manock") to produce such a case design.[[53]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201571–74-53) Apple employee #5 [Rod Holt](/wiki/Rod_Holt "Rod Holt") developed the [switching power supply](/wiki/Switched-mode_power_supply "Switched-mode power supply").[[54]](#cite_note-wozorgAppleII-54) While early Apple II models use ordinary cassette tapes as storage devices, they were superseded in 1978 by the introduction of a 5+1⁄4-inch [floppy disk](/wiki/Floppy_disk "Floppy disk") drive and interface called the [Disk II](/wiki/Disk_II "Disk II").[[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-55)[[56]](#cite_note-56) The Disk II system was designed by Wozniak and released with a retail price of $495.[[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-55)

In 1979, the Apple II was chosen to be the desktop platform for what became the first [killer application](/wiki/Killer_application "Killer application") of the business world: [VisiCalc](/wiki/VisiCalc "VisiCalc"), a [spreadsheet](/wiki/Spreadsheet "Spreadsheet").[[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-55) So important that the Apple II became what [John Markoff](/wiki/John_Markoff "John Markoff") described as a "VisiCalc accessory",[[57]](#cite_note-markoff19820705-57) the application unexpectedly created a business market for the computer; Wozniak later said that small businesses bought 90% of Apple IIs, not the hobbyists he and Jobs had expected.[[58]](#cite_note-byte198501-58) It gave home users an additional reason to buy Apples: Compatibility with the office.[[55]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200413–15-55) Before VisiCalc, Apple had been a distant third place competitor to [Commodore](/wiki/Commodore_64 "Commodore 64") and [Tandy](/wiki/Tandy_Computers "Tandy Computers").[[59]](#cite_note-59)[[60]](#cite_note-60)

The Apple II was one of the three "[1977 Trinity](/wiki/History_of_personal_computers#1977_and_the_emergence_of_the_"Trinity" "History of personal computers")" computers generally credited with creating the [home computer](/wiki/Home_computer "Home computer") market (the other two being the [Commodore PET](/wiki/Commodore_PET "Commodore PET") and the Tandy Corporation [TRS-80](/wiki/TRS-80 "TRS-80")).[[61]](#cite_note-61) A number of different models of the Apple II were built thereafter, including the [Apple IIe](/wiki/Apple_IIe "Apple IIe") and [Apple IIGS](/wiki/Apple_IIGS "Apple IIGS"),[[62]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200417–20-62) which continued in public use for nearly two decades. The [Apple II series](/wiki/Apple_II "Apple II") went on to sell about six million units in total before it was discontinued in 1993.[[63]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson201584–85-63)[[64]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201665–66-64)

### Apple III

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Apple III")]

Main article: [Apple III](/wiki/Apple_III "Apple III")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Apple3.jpg/250px-Apple3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple3.jpg)

[Apple III](/wiki/Apple_III "Apple III") with [Apple Monitor III](/wiki/Apple_Monitor_III "Apple Monitor III")

While the Apple II was already established as a successful business-ready platform because of VisiCalc, Apple management was not content. The Apple III was designed to take on the business environment in an attempt to compete with [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") in the business and corporate computing market.[[65]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Grady20096-65) The development of the Apple III started in late 1978 under the guidance of Wendell Sander,[[66]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200481–82-66) and was subsequently developed by a committee headed by Jobs.[[67]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200441–42-67) The Apple III was first announced on May 19, 1980, with a retail price ranging from $4,340
to $7,800, and released in November 1980.[[67]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200441–42-67)

The Apple III was a conservative design for the era, however Jobs wanted the heat generated by the electronics to be dissipated through the [chassis](/wiki/Chassis "Chassis") of the machine rather than by the more usual cooling fan. The case was not sufficient to cool the components and the Apple III was prone to overheating, causing the [integrated circuit](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit") chips to disconnect from the motherboard. Customers who contacted Apple customer service were told to raise their computers into the air, and then let go to cause the integrated circuits to fall back into place. Thousands of Apple III computers were recalled. A new model was introduced in 1983 to try to rectify the problems, but the damage was already done.

### Apple IPO

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Apple IPO")]

In the July 1980 issue of *[Kilobaud Microcomputing](/wiki/Kilobaud_Microcomputing "Kilobaud Microcomputing")*, publisher [Wayne Green](/wiki/Wayne_Green "Wayne Green") stated that "the best consumer ads I've seen have been those by Apple. They are attention-getting, and they must be prompting sale."[[68]](#cite_note-green198007-68) In August, the *[Financial Times](/wiki/Financial_Times "Financial Times")* reported that

> Apple Computer, the fast growing Californian manufacturer of small computers for the consumer, business and educational markets, is planning to go public later this year. [It] is the largest private manufacturer in the U.S. of small computers. Founded about five years ago as a small workshop business, it has become the second largest manufacturer of small computers, after the [Radio Shack](/wiki/Radio_Shack "Radio Shack") division of the [Tandy](/wiki/Tandy_Corporation "Tandy Corporation") company.[[69]](#cite_note-69)

On December 12, 1980, Apple went public on the [NASDAQ](/wiki/NASDAQ "NASDAQ") stock exchange with the ticker symbol "AAPL", selling 4.6 million shares at $22 per share ($.10 per share when adjusting for [stock splits](/wiki/Stock_split "Stock split") as of November 30, 2020[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit)),[[70]](#cite_note-Apple_FAQ-70) generating over $100 million, which was more capital than any IPO since [Ford Motor Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company") in 1956.[[71]](#cite_note-EDNAAPLSTOCK-71) Several venture capitalists cashed out, reaping billions in long-term capital gains. By the end of the day, the stock rose to $29 per share and 300 millionaires were created, including the two Steves.[[72]](#cite_note-CNBC-72)[[73]](#cite_note-DEDIPO-73) Around this time Wozniak offered $10 million of his own stock to early Apple employees, something Jobs refused to do.[[72]](#cite_note-CNBC-72) Apple's market cap was $1.778 billion at the end of its first day of trading.[[71]](#cite_note-EDNAAPLSTOCK-71)[[73]](#cite_note-DEDIPO-73)

In January 1981, Apple held its first shareholders meeting as a public company in the [Flint Center](/wiki/Flint_Center "Flint Center"), a large auditorium at nearby [De Anza College](/wiki/De_Anza_College "De Anza College") (which is often used for symphony concerts) to handle the larger numbers of shareholders post-IPO. The business of the meeting had been planned so that the voting could be staged in 15 minutes or less. In most cases, voting proxies are collected by mail and counted days or months before a meeting. In this case, after the IPO, many shares were in new hands.

Jobs started his prepared speech, but after being interrupted by voting several times, he dropped his prepared speech and delivered a long, emotionally charged talk about betrayal, lack of respect, and related topics.[[74]](#cite_note-74) The results of the vote were surprising: a young programmer, [Randy Wigginton](/wiki/Randy_Wigginton "Randy Wigginton"), received enough votes to be added to Apple's board of directors, through the use of [cumulative voting](/wiki/Cumulative_voting "Cumulative voting") by a few major shareholders.

### Competition from the IBM PC

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Competition from the IBM PC")]

By August 1981 Apple was among the three largest microcomputer companies, perhaps having replaced Radio Shack as the leader;[[75]](#cite_note-hogan19810831-75) revenue in the first half of the year had already exceeded 1980's $118 million, and *InfoWorld* reported that lack of production capacity was constraining growth.[[76]](#cite_note-hogan19810914state-76) Because of VisiCalc, businesses purchased 90% of Apple II computers;[[77]](#cite_note-Mace1984-77)[[58]](#cite_note-byte198501-58) large customers especially preferred Apple.[[78]](#cite_note-mcmullen19840221-78)

[IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") entered the personal computer market that month with the [IBM PC](/wiki/IBM_Personal_Computer "IBM Personal Computer")[[79]](#cite_note-pollack19810813-79)[[80]](#cite_note-isaacson2013-80) in part because it did not want products without IBM logos on customers' desks,[[81]](#cite_note-pollack19830327-81) but Apple had many advantages. While IBM began with one microcomputer, little available hardware or software, and a couple of hundred dealers, Apple had five times as many dealers in the US and an established international distribution network. The Apple II had an [installed base](/wiki/Installed_base "Installed base") of more than 250,000 customers, and hundreds of independent developers offered software and peripherals; at least ten databases and ten word processors were available, while the PC had no databases and one word processor.[[82]](#cite_note-rosen19811130-82)

The company's customers gained a reputation for devotion and loyalty. *[BYTE](/wiki/BYTE "BYTE")* in 1984 stated that[[83]](#cite_note-lemmons198412-83)

> There are two kinds of people in the world: people who say Apple isn't just a company, it's a cause; and people who say Apple isn't a cause, it's just a company. Both groups are right. Nature has suspended the principle of noncontradiction where Apple is concerned.
> Apple is more than just a company because its founding has some of the qualities of myth ... Apple is two guys in a garage undertaking the mission of bringing computing power, once reserved for big corporations, to ordinary individuals with ordinary budgets. The company's growth from two guys to a billion-dollar corporation exemplifies the [American Dream](/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream"). Even as a large corporation, Apple plays [David to IBM's Goliath](/wiki/David_and_Goliath "David and Goliath"), and thus has the sympathetic role in that myth.

The magazine noted that the loyalty was not entirely positive for Apple; customers were willing to overlook real flaws in its products, even while holding the company to a higher standard than for competitors.[[83]](#cite_note-lemmons198412-83) The Apple III was an example of its autocratic reputation among dealers[[78]](#cite_note-mcmullen19840221-78) that one described as "Apple arrogance".[[84]](#cite_note-dvorak19831128-84) After examining a PC and finding it unimpressive, Apple confidently purchased a full-page advertisement in *The Wall Street Journal* with the headline "Welcome, IBM. Seriously".[[85]](#cite_note-iw19811005-85)[[80]](#cite_note-isaacson2013-80) The company prioritized the III for three years, spending what Wozniak estimated as $100 million on marketing and R&D while not improving the Apple II to compete with the PC, as doing so could hurt III sales.[[58]](#cite_note-byte198501-58)

Microsoft head [Bill Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") was at Apple headquarters the day of IBM's announcement and later said "They didn't seem to care. It took them a full year to realize what had happened".[[80]](#cite_note-isaacson2013-80) The PC almost completely ended sales of the III, the company's most comparable product. The II still sold well,[[81]](#cite_note-pollack19830327-81) with Apple being the leading computer manufacturer in the United States where 7 million units were sold between 1978 and 1982.[[86]](#cite_note-86) But by 1983, the PC surpassed the Apple II as the best-selling personal computer.[[87]](#cite_note-sanger19850805-87) IBM recruited the best Apple dealers while avoiding the discount [grey market](/wiki/Grey_market#Electronics "Grey market") they disliked.[[81]](#cite_note-pollack19830327-81) The head of a retail chain said "It appears that IBM had a better understanding of why the Apple II was successful than had Apple".[[78]](#cite_note-mcmullen19840221-78) [Gene Amdahl](/wiki/Gene_Amdahl "Gene Amdahl") predicted that Apple would be another of the many "brash young companies" that IBM had defeated.[[88]](#cite_note-greenwald19830711-88)

By 1984 the press called the two companies archrivals,[[89]](#cite_note-bulman19841105-89) but IBM had $4 billion in annual PC revenue, more than twice that of Apple and as much as the sales of it and the next three companies combined.[[90]](#cite_note-libes198509-90) A *[Fortune](/wiki/Fortune_(magazine) "Fortune (magazine)")* survey found that 56% of American companies with personal computers used IBM PCs, compared to 16% for Apple.[[91]](#cite_note-Kennedy_1985-91) Small businesses, schools, and some homes became the II's primary market.[[77]](#cite_note-Mace1984-77)

### Xerox PARC and the Lisa

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Xerox PARC and the Lisa")]

Main article: [Apple Lisa](/wiki/Apple_Lisa "Apple Lisa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Apple_Lisa-2-IMG_1730_modified.png/250px-Apple_Lisa-2-IMG_1730_modified.png)](/wiki/File:Apple_Lisa-2-IMG_1730_modified.png)

[Apple Lisa](/wiki/Apple_Lisa "Apple Lisa")

Apple Computer's business division was focused on the Apple III, another iteration of the text-based computer. Simultaneously the Lisa group worked on a new machine that would feature a completely different interface and introduce the words *[mouse](/wiki/Computer_mouse "Computer mouse")*, *[icon](/wiki/Icon_(computing) "Icon (computing)")*, and *[desktop](/wiki/Desktop_metaphor "Desktop metaphor")* into the [lexicon](/wiki/Lexicon "Lexicon") of the computing public. In return for the right to buy US$1,000,000 of pre-[IPO](/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering") stock, Xerox granted Apple Computer three days access to the PARC facilities. After visiting PARC, they came away with new ideas that would complete the foundation for Apple Computer's first [GUI](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface") computer, the [Apple Lisa](/wiki/Apple_Lisa "Apple Lisa").[[92]](#cite_note-92)[[93]](#cite_note-93)[[94]](#cite_note-94)[[95]](#cite_note-95) The first iteration of Apple's [WIMP](/wiki/WIMP_(computing) "WIMP (computing)") interface was a floppy disk where files could be spatially moved around. After months of usability testing, Apple designed the Lisa interface of windows and icons. The Lisa was introduced in 1983 at a cost of US$9,995 (equivalent to $31,600 in 2024). Because of the high price, Lisa failed to penetrate the business market.

### Macintosh and the "1984" commercial

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Macintosh and the \"1984\" commercial")]

Main articles: [History of the Macintosh](/wiki/History_of_the_Macintosh "History of the Macintosh") and [1984 (advertisement)](/wiki/1984_(advertisement) "1984 (advertisement)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png/250px-Macintosh%2C_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png)](/wiki/File:Macintosh,_Google_NY_office_computer_museum_cropped.png)

[Macintosh 128K](/wiki/Macintosh_128K "Macintosh 128K")

By 1984 computer dealers saw Apple as the only clear alternative to IBM's influence;[[96]](#cite_note-sanger19841119-96) some even promoted its products to reduce dependence on the PC.[[81]](#cite_note-pollack19830327-81) The company announced the [Macintosh 128K](/wiki/Macintosh_128K "Macintosh 128K") to the press in October 1983, followed by an 18-page brochure included with magazines in December.[[97]](#cite_note-97) Its debut was announced by a single national broadcast of a US$1.5 million television commercial, "[1984](/wiki/1984_(advertisement) "1984 (advertisement)")" (equivalent to $4,500,000 in 2024). Directed by [Ridley Scott](/wiki/Ridley_Scott "Ridley Scott") and aired during the third quarter of [Super Bowl XVIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XVIII "Super Bowl XVIII") on January 22, 1984,[[98]](#cite_note-98) it is considered a "watershed event"[[99]](#cite_note-99) and a "masterpiece."[[100]](#cite_note-masterpiece-100) The commercial alludes to [George Orwell](/wiki/George_Orwell "George Orwell")'s novel *[Nineteen Eighty-Four](/wiki/Nineteen_Eighty-Four "Nineteen Eighty-Four")* which describes a [dystopian future](/wiki/Dystopia "Dystopia") of enforced conformity. In the commercial a heroine represents the coming of the Macintosh to save humanity,[[101]](#cite_note-cellini-101) and ends with the words: "On January 24th, Apple Computer will introduce Macintosh. And you'll see why 1984 won't be like 1984.”[[102]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004110–113-102)

On January 24, 1984, the Macintosh went on sale with a retail price of $2,495.[[103]](#cite_note-103)[[104]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200491-104) It came bundled with two applications designed to show off its interface: [MacWrite](/wiki/MacWrite "MacWrite") and [MacPaint](/wiki/MacPaint "MacPaint"). On the same day, an emotional Jobs introduced the computer to a wildly enthusiastic audience at Apple's annual shareholders meeting held in the Flint Auditorium;[[105]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015167–170-105)[[106]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201682–83-106) Macintosh engineer [Andy Hertzfeld](/wiki/Andy_Hertzfeld "Andy Hertzfeld") described the scene as "pandemonium".[[107]](#cite_note-The_Times_They_Are_A-Changin-107) Jobs had directed the development of the [Macintosh](/wiki/Mac_(computer) "Mac (computer)") since 1981, when he took over the project from early Apple employee [Jef Raskin](/wiki/Jef_Raskin "Jef Raskin"), who conceived the computer,[[108]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Grady20098–10-108)[[109]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015109–112-109) and Wozniak, who led the initial design and development with Raskin but was on leave during this time due to an airplane crash earlier that year, making it easier for Jobs to take over the program.[[110]](#cite_note-TheVerge-110)[[111]](#cite_note-wozorg-111) The Macintosh was based on [The Lisa](/wiki/Apple_Lisa "Apple Lisa") (and [Xerox PARC's](/wiki/PARC_user_interface "PARC user interface") [mouse](/wiki/Computer_mouse "Computer mouse")-driven [graphical user interface](/wiki/Graphical_user_interface "Graphical user interface")),[[112]](#cite_note-Wired-112)[[113]](#cite_note-Jobsjourney-113) and it was widely acclaimed by the media with strong initial sales supporting it.[[114]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015185–187-114)[[115]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201684–88-115) However, the slow processing speed and limited software led to a rapid sales decline in the second half of 1984.[[114]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015185–187-114)[[115]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201684–88-115)[[116]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer200498-116)

The Macintosh was too radical for some, who labeled it a mere "toy". Because the machine was entirely designed around the GUI, existing text-mode and [command-driven applications](/wiki/Command_line_interface "Command line interface") had to be redesigned and the programming code rewritten; this was a challenging undertaking that many [software developers](/wiki/Software_developer "Software developer") shied away from, and resulted in an initial lack of software for the new system. In April 1984 [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft")'s [Multiplan](/wiki/Multiplan "Multiplan") migrated over from [MS-DOS](/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS"), followed by [Microsoft Word](/wiki/Microsoft_Word "Microsoft Word") in January 1985;[[117]](#cite_note-hotwyu-117) in return for Microsoft's commitment to Macintosh, Apple agreed to not provide [software development kits](/wiki/Software_development_kit "Software development kit") and prototype computers to companies with applications competing with Microsoft's.[[118]](#cite_note-farber20140123-118) In 1985, [Lotus Software](/wiki/Lotus_Software "Lotus Software") introduced [Lotus Jazz](/wiki/Lotus_Jazz "Lotus Jazz") after the success of [Lotus 1-2-3](/wiki/Lotus_1-2-3 "Lotus 1-2-3") for the IBM PC, although it was largely a flop.[[119]](#cite_note-119) Apple introduced [Macintosh Office](/wiki/Macintosh_Office "Macintosh Office") the same year with the [lemmings ad](/wiki/Lemmings_(television_commercial) "Lemmings (television commercial)"), infamous for insulting potential customers. It was not successful.[[120]](#cite_note-Worst_Business-120)

For a special post-election edition of *[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek "Newsweek")* in November 1984, Apple spent more than US$2.5 million to buy all 39 of the advertising pages in the issue.[[121]](#cite_note-121) Apple also ran a "Test Drive a Macintosh" promotion, in which potential buyers with a credit card could take home a Macintosh for 24 hours and return it to a dealer afterwards. While 200,000 people participated, dealers disliked the promotion, the supply of computers was insufficient for demand, and many were returned in such a bad shape that they could no longer be sold. This marketing campaign caused CEO [John Sculley](/wiki/John_Sculley "John Sculley") to raise the price from US$1,995 (equivalent to $6,000 in 2024) to US$2,495 (equivalent to $7,600 in 2024).[[120]](#cite_note-Worst_Business-120)

### Jobs and Wozniak leave Apple

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Jobs and Wozniak leave Apple")]

By early 1985, the Macintosh's failure to defeat the IBM PC[[114]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015185–187-114)[[115]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201684–88-115) triggered a power struggle between Jobs and CEO [John Sculley](/wiki/John_Sculley "John Sculley"), who had been hired two years earlier by Jobs[[122]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156-122)[[123]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2015153–154-123) using the famous line, "Do you want to sell sugar water for the rest of your life or come with me and change the world?"[[124]](#cite_note-124) Sculley and Jobs' visions for the company greatly differed. The former favored [open architecture](/wiki/Open_architecture "Open architecture") computers like the Apple II, sold to education, small business, and home markets less vulnerable to IBM. Jobs wanted the company to focus on the [closed architecture](/wiki/Closed_architecture "Closed architecture") Macintosh as a business alternative to the IBM PC. President and CEO Sculley had little control over chairman of the Board Jobs' Macintosh division; it and the Apple II division operated like separate companies, duplicating services.[[125]](#cite_note-robbeloth198510_11-125) Although its products provided 85% of Apple's sales in early 1985, the company's January 1985 [annual meeting](/wiki/Annual_meeting "Annual meeting") did not mention the Apple II division or employees. This frustrated Wozniak, who left active employment at Apple in the spring of that year to pursue other ventures, stating that the company had "been going in the wrong direction for the last five years" and sold most of his stock.[[126]](#cite_note-rice19850415-126)[[127]](#cite_note-wozemployee-127)[[128]](#cite_note-128) Despite these grievances, Wozniak left the company amicably and as of January 2018 continues to represent Apple at events or in interviews,[[127]](#cite_note-wozemployee-127) receiving a stipend over the years for this role estimated in 2006 to be $120,000 per year.[[129]](#cite_note-iWoz-129) Wozniak also remained an Apple shareholder following his departure.[[130]](#cite_note-wozstock-130)

Wozniak's first venture after leaving Apple was founding [CL 9](/wiki/CL_9 "CL 9") in 1985 and creating the first programmable [universal remote](/wiki/Universal_remote "Universal remote") control two years later, called the "CORE", stating that "I never felt like I was turning my back on my own company [Apple]." He told Apple's director of engineering [Wayne Rosing](/wiki/Wayne_Rosing "Wayne Rosing") about his decision to step away from the company, but not his longtime business partner and friend Steve Jobs. Wozniak guessed that Jobs first heard the news from an article in *[The Wall Street Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")* where he mentioned that he wasn't leaving because he was disgruntled with Apple, but that he was excited to build a new remote control. The article nevertheless included some of Wozniak's criticisms of Apple, and Wozniak later said "it was an accident, but it's been picked up by every book and every bit of history [since]."[[129]](#cite_note-iWoz-129): 289

In April 1985, Sculley decided to remove Jobs as the general manager of the Macintosh division, and gained unanimous support from the Apple board of directors.[[131]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlender201687–92-131)[[122]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156-122) Rather than submit to Sculley's direction, Jobs attempted to oust him from his leadership role at Apple.[[132]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157-132) Informed by [Jean-Louis Gassée](/wiki/Jean-Louis_Gass%C3%A9e "Jean-Louis Gassée"), Sculley found out that Jobs had been attempting to organize a [coup](/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat#Other "Coup d'état") and called an emergency executive meeting at which Apple's executive staff sided with Sculley and stripped Jobs of all operational duties.[[132]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinzmayer2004156–157-132)

Jobs, while taking the position of chairman of the firm, had no influence over Apple's direction and resigned in September 1985, taking a number of Apple employees with him to found [NeXT Inc.](/wiki/NeXT "NeXT")[[133]](#cite_note-133) In a show of defiance at being set aside by Apple Computer, Jobs sold all but one of his 6.5 million shares in the company for $70 million. Jobs then acquired the [visual effects](/wiki/Visual_effects "Visual effects") house, [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") for $5M (equivalent to $14,300,000 in 2024). NeXT Inc. built computers with futuristic designs and the UNIX-derived [NEXTSTEP](/wiki/NEXTSTEP "NEXTSTEP") operating system. NeXTSTEP eventually developed into Mac OS X. While not a commercial success, due in part to its high price, the NeXT computer introduced important concepts to the history of the personal computer, including serving as the initial platform for [Tim Berners-Lee](/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee "Tim Berners-Lee") as he was developing the [World Wide Web](/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web").[[134]](#cite_note-134)

Sculley reorganized the company, unifying sales and marketing in one division and product operations and development in another.[[135]](#cite_note-135)[[125]](#cite_note-robbeloth198510_11-125) Despite initial marketing difficulties, the Macintosh brand was eventually a success for Apple, due to its introduction of [desktop publishing](/wiki/Desktop_publishing "Desktop publishing") (and later [computer animation](/wiki/Computer_animation "Computer animation")) through Apple's partnership with [Adobe Systems](/wiki/Adobe_Systems "Adobe Systems"), which introduced the [laser printer](/wiki/Laser_printer "Laser printer") and [Adobe PageMaker](/wiki/Adobe_PageMaker "Adobe PageMaker"). The Macintosh became the default platform for many arts industries including cinema, music, advertising, and publishing.

## 1985–1997: Sculley, Spindler, Amelio

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: 1985–1997: Sculley, Spindler, Amelio")]

### Corporate performance

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Corporate performance")]

See also: [List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple](/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Apple "List of mergers and acquisitions by Apple")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Macintosh_SE.jpg/250px-Macintosh_SE.jpg)](/wiki/File:Macintosh_SE.jpg)

[Macintosh SE](/wiki/Macintosh_SE "Macintosh SE") (1987)

Under leadership of [John Sculley](/wiki/John_Sculley "John Sculley"), Apple issued its first corporate stock dividend on May 11, 1987. A month later on June 16, Apple stock split for the first time in a 2:1 split. Between March 1988 and January 1989, Apple undertook five acquisitions, including software companies Network Innovations,[[136]](#cite_note-136) Styleware,[[137]](#cite_note-137) Nashoba Systems,[[138]](#cite_note-138) and Coral Software,[[139]](#cite_note-139) as well as satellite communications company Orion Network Systems.[[140]](#cite_note-140)

Apple continued to sell both lines of its computers, the Apple II and the Macintosh. A few months after introducing the Mac, Apple released a compact version of the Apple II called the [Apple IIc](/wiki/Apple_IIc "Apple IIc"). And in 1986 Apple introduced the [Apple IIGS](/wiki/Apple_IIGS "Apple IIGS"), an Apple II positioned as something of a hybrid product with a mouse-driven, Mac-like operating environment. Even with the release of the first Macintosh, Apple II computers remained the main source of income for Apple for years.[[141]](#cite_note-141)

### The Mac family

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: The Mac family")]

See also: [Timeline of Macintosh models](/wiki/Timeline_of_Macintosh_models "Timeline of Macintosh models")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Powerbook_100_pose.jpg/250px-Powerbook_100_pose.jpg)](/wiki/File:Powerbook_100_pose.jpg)

[PowerBook 100](/wiki/PowerBook_100 "PowerBook 100") (1991)

At the same time, the Mac was becoming a product family of its own. The original model evolved into the [Mac Plus](/wiki/Macintosh_Plus "Macintosh Plus") in 1986 and spawned the [Mac SE](/wiki/Macintosh_SE "Macintosh SE") and the [Mac II](/wiki/Macintosh_II "Macintosh II") in 1987 and the [Mac Classic](/wiki/Macintosh_Classic "Macintosh Classic") and [Mac LC](/wiki/Macintosh_LC "Macintosh LC") in 1990. Meanwhile, Apple attempted its first portable Macs: the failed [Macintosh Portable](/wiki/Macintosh_Portable "Macintosh Portable") in 1989 and then the more popular [PowerBook](/wiki/PowerBook "PowerBook") in 1991, a landmark product that established the modern form and [ergonomic](/wiki/Ergonomics "Ergonomics") layout of the laptop. Popular products and increasing revenues made this a good time for Apple. [MacAddict](/wiki/MacAddict "MacAddict") magazine has called 1989 to 1991 the "first golden age" of the Macintosh. On February 19, 1987, Apple registered the "[Apple.com](/wiki/Apple.com "Apple.com")" domain name, making it one of the first hundred companies to register a [.com](/wiki/.com ".com") address on the nascent Internet.[[142]](#cite_note-142)

### Early-mid-1990s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Early-mid-1990s")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Apple_Newton_MessagePad_100_with_stylus.jpg/250px-Apple_Newton_MessagePad_100_with_stylus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Newton_MessagePad_100_with_stylus.jpg)

[Apple Newton MessagePad](/wiki/MessagePad "MessagePad") (1993)

In the late 1980s, Apple's fiercest technological rivals were the [Amiga](/wiki/Amiga "Amiga") and [Atari ST](/wiki/Atari_ST "Atari ST") platforms. But computers based on the [IBM PC](/wiki/IBM_PC "IBM PC") were far more popular than all three, and by the 1990s, they finally had a comparable [GUI](/wiki/GUI "GUI") thanks to [Windows 3.0](/wiki/Windows_3.0 "Windows 3.0"), and were out-competing Apple.

Apple's response to the PC threat was a profusion of new Macintosh lines including [Quadra](/wiki/Macintosh_Quadra "Macintosh Quadra"), [Centris](/wiki/Macintosh_Centris "Macintosh Centris"), and [Performa](/wiki/Macintosh_Performa "Macintosh Performa"). These new lines were marketed poorly by what was now "arguably one of the worst-managed companies in the industry".[[143]](#cite_note-alsop19960205-143) There were too many models, differentiated by very minor graduations in [technical specifications](/wiki/Technical_specifications "Technical specifications"). The profusion of arbitrary model numbers confused consumers and hurt Apple's reputation for simplicity. Resellers like [Sears](/wiki/Sears,_Roebuck_and_Company "Sears, Roebuck and Company") and [CompUSA](/wiki/CompUSA "CompUSA") often failed to sell or even competently display these Macs. Inventory grew as Apple consistently underestimated demand for popular models and overestimated demand for others.[[143]](#cite_note-alsop19960205-143)

In 1991, Apple partnered with long-time competitor [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") and [Motorola](/wiki/Motorola "Motorola") to form the [AIM alliance](/wiki/AIM_alliance "AIM alliance"), with the ultimate goal to create a revolutionary new computing platform, known as [PReP](/wiki/PReP "PReP"), using IBM and Motorola hardware and Apple software. As the first step, Apple started the [Power Macintosh](/wiki/Power_Macintosh "Power Macintosh") line in 1994, using [PowerPC](/wiki/PowerPC "PowerPC") processors from Motorola and IBM. The [RISC](/wiki/RISC "RISC") architecture of these processors differed substantially from the Motorola [680X0](/wiki/68000 "68000") series used by previous Macs. Parts of Apple's operating system were rewritten to allow some older Mac software to run in [emulation](/wiki/Emulator "Emulator") on the PowerPC series.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] Apple refused IBM's offer to purchase the company, but later unsuccessfully sought another offer from IBM,[[144]](#cite_note-markoff19970901-144) and at one point was "hours away" from an acquisition by [Sun Microsystems](/wiki/Sun_Microsystems "Sun Microsystems").[[143]](#cite_note-alsop19960205-143)[[145]](#cite_note-preimesberger20110225-145) In 1993, Apple released the [Newton](/wiki/Newton_(platform) "Newton (platform)"), a failed early [personal digital assistant](/wiki/Personal_digital_assistant "Personal digital assistant") (PDA).

### Need for a new OS

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Need for a new OS")]

In 1994 Apple launched [eWorld](/wiki/EWorld "EWorld"), an online service providing email, news and a bulletin board system to replace [AppleLink](/wiki/AppleLink "AppleLink"). It was shut down in 1996.[[146]](#cite_note-146) In 1995, to achieve deeper market penetration and extra revenue, Apple officially began licensing the Mac OS and Macintosh ROMs to 3rd party manufacturers. The "[Clonintoshes](/wiki/Clonintosh "Clonintosh")" competed with Apple's own Mac's and reduced Apple's sales.[[147]](#cite_note-lemjosh-147) Apple had market share of over 10% until Jobs was re-hired in 1997 as interim CEO to replace Gil Amelio, and found a loophole to terminate the Macintosh OS licensing program. Macintosh's market share fell to around 3%.[[148]](#cite_note-148)

During the 90's, "project *Pink*" had Apple and IBM collaborating to develop a new operating system, named *[Taligent](/wiki/Taligent "Taligent")* to replace *[System 7](/wiki/System_7 "System 7")*. Infighting resulted in Apple leaving the project and IBM finishing it. Apple started project *[Copland](/wiki/Copland_(operating_system) "Copland (operating system)")*, another effort to replace System 7, but it was affected by [Feature creep](/wiki/Feature_creep "Feature creep") then [Development hell](/wiki/Development_hell "Development hell") due to software planned for Taligent being reworked for Copland. Ultimately Copland was scrapped.[[149]](#cite_note-149) With the Copland project in disarray, Apple decided it needed to acquire another company's operating system. Candidates considered were [Sun](/wiki/Sun_Microsystems "Sun Microsystems")'s [Solaris](/wiki/Solaris_(operating_system) "Solaris (operating system)") and [Windows NT](/wiki/Windows_NT "Windows NT"). Hancock was in favor of Solaris, while Amelio preferred Windows. Amelio called [Bill Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates"), and Gates promised Microsoft engineers would port [QuickDraw](/wiki/QuickDraw "QuickDraw") to NT.[[150]](#cite_note-150)

### Acquisition of NeXT

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Acquisition of NeXT")]

In 1996, the struggling [NeXT](/wiki/NeXT "NeXT") company beat Be Inc.'s [BeOS](/wiki/BeOS "BeOS") bid to sell its operating system to Apple.[[151]](#cite_note-151) On December 20, 1996, Apple announced it would purchase NeXT, and its NeXTstep operating system, for $429 million and 1.5 million shares of Apple stock.[[152]](#cite_note-apple-acquisition-152) This brought Jobs back to Apple's management for the first time since 1985, and NeXT technology became the foundation of the [Mac OS X](/wiki/Mac_OS_X "Mac OS X") operating system.

## 1997–2001: Apple's comeback

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: 1997–2001: Apple's comeback")]

### Return of Steve Jobs

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Return of Steve Jobs")]

On July 9, 1997, [Gil Amelio](/wiki/Gil_Amelio "Gil Amelio") was ousted as CEO of Apple by the board of directors. [Fred D. Anderson](/wiki/Fred_D._Anderson "Fred D. Anderson") was the head of the directors in short term and obtained short-term working capital from the banks in July 1997.[[153]](#cite_note-153)[[154]](#cite_note-154) In August 1997, Jobs stepped in as the interim CEO to begin a critical restructuring of the company's product line.[[5]](#cite_note-interim_CEO-5) He eventually became CEO and served in that position from January 2000 to August 2011.[[6]](#cite_note-norr-6) On August 24, 2011, Jobs resigned his position as chief executive officer of Apple before his long battle with pancreatic cancer took his life on October 5, 2011.[[155]](#cite_note-155) On November 10, Apple introduced the [Apple Store](/wiki/Apple_Store_(online) "Apple Store (online)"), an online retail store based upon the [WebObjects](/wiki/WebObjects "WebObjects") application server the company had acquired in its purchase of [NeXT](/wiki/NeXT "NeXT"). The new direct sales outlet was tied to a new build-to-order manufacturing strategy.[[156]](#cite_note-156)[[157]](#cite_note-157)

### Microsoft deal

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Microsoft deal")]

At the 1997 [Macworld Expo](/wiki/Macworld_Expo "Macworld Expo"), Jobs announced that Apple would begin a partnership with [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), with terms including a five-year commitment from Microsoft to release [Microsoft Office](/wiki/Microsoft_Office "Microsoft Office") for Macintosh, and a US$150 million investment in Apple. The long-standing dispute over whether Windows infringed Apple patents was settled,[[158]](#cite_note-Microsoft_investment-158) and [Internet Explorer](/wiki/Internet_Explorer_for_Mac "Internet Explorer for Mac") would ship as the Macintosh's default browser, with the user able to have a preference. Microsoft chairman [Bill Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") appeared on-screen explaining plans for developing Mac software, and expressing excitement to be helping Apple return to success. Jobs addressed the audience:

> If we want to move forward and see Apple healthy and prospering again, we have to let go of a few things here. We have to let go of this notion that for Apple to win, Microsoft has to lose. We have to embrace a notion that for Apple to win, Apple has to do a really good job. And if others are going to help us that's great, because we need all the help we can get, and if we screw up and we don't do a good job, it's not somebody else's fault, it's our fault. So I think that is a very important perspective. If we want Microsoft Office on the Mac, we better treat the company that puts it out with a little bit of gratitude; we'd like their software.
> So, the era of setting this up as a competition between Apple and Microsoft is over as far as I'm concerned. This is about getting Apple healthy, this is about Apple being able to make incredibly great contributions to the industry and to get healthy and prosper again.[[159]](#cite_note-159)

The day before the announcement Apple had a market cap of $2.46 billion,[[160]](#cite_note-160) and had ended its previous quarter with quarterly revenues of US$1.7 billion and cash reserves of US$1.2 billion,[[161]](#cite_note-161) making the US$150 million amount of the investment largely symbolic. Apple CFO Fred Anderson stated that Apple would use the additional funds to invest in its core markets of education and creative content.[[158]](#cite_note-Microsoft_investment-158)

### iMac, iBook, and Power Mac G4

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: iMac, iBook, and Power Mac G4")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/IMac_Bondi_Blue.jpg/250px-IMac_Bondi_Blue.jpg)](/wiki/File:IMac_Bondi_Blue.jpg)

The original [iMac](/wiki/IMac "IMac") (iMac G3) released in 1998

While discontinuing Apple's licensing of its operating system to third-party computer manufacturers, one of Jobs's first moves as new acting CEO was to develop the [iMac](/wiki/IMac "IMac"), which bought Apple time to restructure. The original iMac integrated a CRT display and CPU into a streamlined, translucent plastic body. The line became a sales smash, moving about one million units each year. It helped re-introduce Apple to the media and public and announced the company's new emphasis on the design and aesthetics of its products.

In 1999, Apple introduced the [Power Mac G4](/wiki/Power_Mac_G4 "Power Mac G4"), which utilized the Motorola-made PowerPC 7400 containing a 128-bit instruction unit known as [AltiVec](/wiki/AltiVec "AltiVec"), its flagship processor line. Apple unveiled the [iBook](/wiki/IBook "IBook") that year, its first consumer-oriented laptop, the first Macintosh to support the use of [Wireless LAN](/wiki/Wireless_LAN "Wireless LAN") via the optional AirPort card. Based on the 802.11b standard, it helped popularize Wireless LAN technology to connect computers to networks.

### Mac OS X

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Mac OS X")]

Main article: [Mac OS X](/wiki/Mac_OS_X "Mac OS X")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg/250px-Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Headquarters_in_Cupertino.jpg)

Company headquarters on Infinite Loop in [Cupertino, California](/wiki/Cupertino,_California "Cupertino, California")

In 2001, Apple introduced [Mac OS X](/wiki/MacOS "MacOS"), an operating system based on [NeXT](/wiki/NeXT "NeXT")'s [NeXTSTEP](/wiki/NeXTSTEP "NeXTSTEP") and incorporating parts of the [FreeBSD](/wiki/FreeBSD "FreeBSD") kernel.[[162]](#cite_note-162) Aimed at consumers and professionals alike, Mac OS X married the stability, reliability and security of [Unix](/wiki/Unix "Unix") with the ease of a completely overhauled user interface. To help users transition, the new operating system allowed the use of Mac OS 9 applications through the [Classic](/wiki/Classic_(Mac_OS_X) "Classic (Mac OS X)") environment. Apple's [Carbon](/wiki/Carbon_(API) "Carbon (API)") API allowed developers to adapt Mac OS 9 software to use Mac OS X's features.

### Retail stores

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Retail stores")]

Main article: [Apple Store](/wiki/Apple_Store "Apple Store")

In May 2001, after much speculation, Apple announced the opening of a line of Apple retail stores, to be located throughout the major U.S. computer buying markets. The stores were designed for two primary purposes: to stem the tide of Apple's declining share of the computer market and to respond to poor marketing of Apple products at third-party retail outlets.

## 2001–2007: iPods, iTunes Store, Intel transition

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: 2001–2007: iPods, iTunes Store, Intel transition")]

### iPod

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: iPod")]

Main article: [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d1/IPod_1G.jpg)](/wiki/File:IPod_1G.jpg)

A 1st-generation [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod") (2001)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/IPod_mini.png/250px-IPod_mini.png)](/wiki/File:IPod_mini.png)

[iPod Mini](/wiki/IPod_Mini "IPod Mini") with the UI (user interface) set to German

In October 2001, Apple introduced its first [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod") portable digital audio player. Then iPod started as a 5 gigabyte player capable of storing around 1000 songs. It then evolved into an array of products including the [Mini](/wiki/IPod_Mini "IPod Mini") (discontinued), the [iPod Touch](/wiki/IPod_Touch "IPod Touch") (discontinued), the [Shuffle](/wiki/IPod_Shuffle "IPod Shuffle") (discontinued), the [iPod Classic](/wiki/IPod_Classic "IPod Classic") (discontinued), the [Nano](/wiki/IPod_Nano "IPod Nano") (discontinued), the [iPhone](/wiki/IPhone "IPhone") and the [iPad](/wiki/IPad "IPad"). Since March 2011, the largest storage capacity for an iPod has been 160 gigabytes.[[163]](#cite_note-163) Speaking to software developers on June 6, 2005, Jobs said the company's share of the entire portable music device market stood at 76%.[[164]](#cite_note-164)

The iPod gave an enormous lift to Apple's financial results.[[165]](#cite_note-165) In the quarter ending March 26, 2005, Apple earned US$290 million, or 34¢ a share, on sales of US$3.24 billion. The year before in the same quarter, Apple earned just US$46 million, or 6¢ a share, on revenue of US$1.91 billion.

### Moving on from colored plastics and the PowerPC G3

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Moving on from colored plastics and the PowerPC G3")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/IMac_G4_sunflower7.png/250px-IMac_G4_sunflower7.png)](/wiki/File:IMac_G4_sunflower7.png)

[iMac G4](/wiki/IMac_G4 "IMac G4") (2002)

In early 2002, Apple unveiled a completely redesigned iMac, using the G4 processor and LCD display. The new [iMac G4](/wiki/IMac_G4 "IMac G4") design had a white hemispherical base and a flat panel all-digital display supported by a swiveling chrome neck. After several iterations increasing the processing speed and screen sizes from 15" to 17" to 20" the iMac G4 was discontinued and replaced by the [iMac G5](/wiki/IMac_G5 "IMac G5") in the summer of 2004.

Later in 2002, Apple released the [Xserve](/wiki/Xserve "Xserve") [1U](/wiki/Rack_unit "Rack unit") [rack mounted](/wiki/Rack_mount "Rack mount") server. Originally featuring two G4 chips, the Xserve was unusual for Apple in two ways. It represented an earnest effort to enter the enterprise computer market, and it was cheaper than competitors' similar machines. This was largely due to Fast ATA drives as opposed to the SCSI hard drives used in traditional rack-mounted servers. Apple later released the [Xserve RAID](/wiki/Xserve_RAID "Xserve RAID"), a 14 drive [RAID](/wiki/RAID "RAID") that was again cheaper than competing systems.

In mid-2003, Jobs launched the [Power Mac G5](/wiki/Power_Mac_G5 "Power Mac G5"), based on [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM")'s [G5 processor](/wiki/PowerPC_970 "PowerPC 970"). Its all-metal [anodized aluminum](/wiki/Anodized_aluminum "Anodized aluminum") chassis finished Apple's transition away from colored plastics in their computers. Apple claims this was the first 64-bit computer sold to the general public. The Power Mac G5 was used by Virginia Tech to build its prototype [System X](/wiki/System_X_(supercomputer) "System X (supercomputer)") supercomputing cluster, which at the time was considered the third-fastest supercomputer in the world. It cost only US$5.2 million to build, far less than the previous No. 3 and other ranking supercomputers. Apple's Xserves were updated to use the G5 as well. They replaced the Power Mac G5 machines as the main building block of [Virginia Tech](/wiki/Virginia_Tech "Virginia Tech")'s [System X](/wiki/System_X_(supercomputer) "System X (supercomputer)"), which was ranked in November 2004 as the world's seventh-fastest [supercomputer](/wiki/Supercomputer "Supercomputer").[[166]](#cite_note-166)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/IMac_G5_-_Frontal_view.png/250px-IMac_G5_-_Frontal_view.png)](/wiki/File:IMac_G5_-_Frontal_view.png)

[iMac G5](/wiki/IMac_G5 "IMac G5") (2004)

A new iMac based on the G5 processor was unveiled August 31, 2004, and was made available in mid-September. This model dispensed with the base altogether, placing the CPU and the rest of the computing hardware behind the flat-panel screen, which is suspended from a streamlined aluminum foot. This new iMac, dubbed the [iMac G5](/wiki/IMac_G5 "IMac G5"), was the "world's thinnest desktop computer",[[167]](#cite_note-167) measuring in at around two inches (around 5 centimeters).[[168]](#cite_note-168)

In 2004, after creating a sizable financial base to work with, the company began experimenting with new parts from new suppliers. Apple could produce new designs quickly, and released the iPod Video, then the iPod Classic, and eventually the iPod touch and iPhone. On April 29, 2005, Apple released [Mac OS X v10.4](/wiki/Mac_OS_X_v10.4 "Mac OS X v10.4") "Tiger".

Apple's successful [PowerBook](/wiki/PowerBook "PowerBook") and [iBook](/wiki/IBook "IBook") relied on previous generation G4 architecture produced by [Freescale Semiconductor](/wiki/Freescale_Semiconductor "Freescale Semiconductor"), a spin-off from Motorola. IBM engineers had some success in making their PowerPC G5 processor consume less power and run cooler, but not enough to run in iBook or PowerBook formats. In October 2005, Apple released the Power Mac G5 Dual featuring a Dual-Core processor – two cores in one rather than two separate processors. The Power Mac G5 Quad uses two Dual-Core processors. The Power Mac G5 Dual cores run individually at 2.0 GHz or 2.3 GHz. The Power Mac G5 Quad cores run individually at 2.5 GHz, and all variations have a graphics processor with 256-bit memory bandwidth.[[169]](#cite_note-169)

### Retail store expansion

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Retail store expansion")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Apple_Store_Ginza_%282006.05%29.jpg/250px-Apple_Store_Ginza_%282006.05%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Store_Ginza_(2006.05).jpg)

Apple Store in Ginza district, [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo")

Initially, [Apple Stores](/wiki/Apple_Store "Apple Store") were only in the United States, but in late 2003, Apple opened its first Apple Store abroad, in Tokyo's [Ginza](/wiki/Ginza "Ginza") district. It was followed by a store in [Osaka](/wiki/Osaka,_Osaka "Osaka, Osaka"), Japan in August 2004. In 2005, Apple opened stores in [Nagoya](/wiki/Nagoya,_Aichi "Nagoya, Aichi"), the [Shibuya](/wiki/Shibuya,_Tokyo "Shibuya, Tokyo") district of Tokyo, [Fukuoka](/wiki/Fukuoka,_Fukuoka "Fukuoka, Fukuoka"), and [Sendai](/wiki/Sendai,_Miyagi "Sendai, Miyagi"). A store opened in [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo,_Hokkaid%C5%8D "Sapporo, Hokkaidō") in 2006. Apple's first European store opened in London, on [Regent Street](/wiki/Regent_Street "Regent Street"), in November 2004. A store in the [Bullring](/wiki/Bull_Ring,_Birmingham "Bull Ring, Birmingham") shopping centre in [Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham") opened in April 2005, and the [Bluewater shopping centre](/wiki/Bluewater_Shopping_Centre "Bluewater Shopping Centre") in [Dartford](/wiki/Dartford "Dartford"), Kent opened in July 2005. Apple opened its first store in Canada in the middle of 2005 at the [Yorkdale Shopping Centre](/wiki/Yorkdale_Shopping_Centre "Yorkdale Shopping Centre") in [North York](/wiki/North_York "North York"), [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"). Later in 2005 Apple opened the [Meadowhall](/wiki/Meadowhall_Centre "Meadowhall Centre") Store in [Sheffield](/wiki/Sheffield "Sheffield") and the [Trafford Centre](/wiki/Trafford_Centre "Trafford Centre") Store in [Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester"), UK. Later additions in the London area include [Brent Cross](/wiki/Brent_Cross "Brent Cross") (January 2006), [Westfield](/wiki/Westfield_London "Westfield London") in Shepherd's Bush (September 2008), and [Covent Garden](/wiki/Covent_Garden "Covent Garden") (August 2010), which at 40,000 square feet (3,700 m2) was, as of 2015, the largest Apple Store in the world.[[170]](#cite_note-170)

Apple opened several "larger" stores in October 2004 to capture markets where demand does not necessarily dictate a full-scale store. The first of these stores was opened at [Stanford Shopping Center](/wiki/Stanford_Shopping_Center "Stanford Shopping Center") in [Palo Alto, California](/wiki/Palo_Alto,_California "Palo Alto, California"). These stores are only one half the square footage of the smallest normal store.

### Apple and "i" Web services

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Apple and \"i\" Web services")]

In 2000, Apple introduced iTools, a set of free web-based tools that included an email account, internet greeting cards called iCards, a Web site review service called [iReview](/wiki/IReview "IReview"), and "KidSafe", to prevent children browsing inappropriate websites. The latter two services were canceled because of lack of success. iCards and email were integrated into Apple's [.Mac](/wiki/.Mac ".Mac") subscription-based service introduced in 2002 and discontinued in mid-2008 to make way for MobileMe, coinciding with the iPhone 3G release. MobileMe, at the same US$99.00 annual subscription as its dotMac predecessor, featured "push" services to instantly and automatically send emails, contacts and calendar updates directly to users' iPhones. Controversy around the release of MobileMe resulted in downtime and a significantly longer release window. Apple extended existing MobileMe subscriptions by 30 days free-of-charge.[[171]](#cite_note-171) At the WWDC event in June 2011, Apple announced [iCloud](/wiki/ICloud "ICloud"), keeping most MobileMe services but dropping iDisk, Gallery, and iWeb. It added Find my Mac, iTunes Match, Photo Stream, Documents & Data Backup, and iCloud backup for iOS devices. The service requires iOS 5 and OS X 10.7 Lion.

### iTunes Store

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: iTunes Store")]

Main article: [iTunes Store](/wiki/ITunes_Store "ITunes Store")

The [iTunes Music Store](/wiki/ITunes_Store "ITunes Store") was launched in April 2003, with 2 million downloads in the first 16 days. Music was purchased through the [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes") application, which was initially Macintosh-only; in October 2003, support for [Windows](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows") was added. Initially, the music store was only available in the United States due to licensing restrictions.

In June 2004 Apple opened its iTunes Music Store in the United Kingdom, France, and Germany. A version for the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") version opened October 2004, but it was not initially available in the [Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") due to the intransigence of the [Irish Recorded Music Association](/wiki/Irish_Recorded_Music_Association "Irish Recorded Music Association") (IRMA) but was opened there a few months later on Thursday, January 6, 2005. A version for Canada opened in December 2004. On May 10, 2005, the iTunes Music Store was expanded to [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark"), Norway, [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden"), and [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland").

On December 16, 2004, Apple sold its 200 millionth song on the iTunes Music Store to Ryan Alekman from [Belchertown, Massachusetts](/wiki/Belchertown,_Massachusetts "Belchertown, Massachusetts"). The download was *[The Complete U2](/wiki/The_Complete_U2 "The Complete U2")*, by [U2](/wiki/U2 "U2").[[172]](#cite_note-172) Just under three months later Apple sold its 300 millionth song on March 2, 2005.[[173]](#cite_note-173) On July 17, 2005, the iTunes Music Store sold its 500 millionth song.[[174]](#cite_note-174) At that point, songs were selling at an accelerating annualized rate of more than 500 million.

On October 25, 2005, the iTunes Store went live in Australia, with songs selling for [A$](/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian dollar")1.69 each, albums at (generally) A$16.99 and music videos and Pixar short films at A$3.39. Before the loophole was closed, people in [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") were briefly able to buy music from the Australian store On February 23, 2006, the iTunes Music Store sold its 1 billionth song.[[175]](#cite_note-175)

The iTunes Music Store changed its name to iTunes Store on September 12, 2006, when it began offering video content (TV shows and movies) for sale. Since iTunes' inception, it has sold over 2 billion songs, 1.2 billion of which were sold in 2006. Since downloadable TV and movie content was added 50 million TV episodes and 1.3 million movies have been downloaded. In early 2010, Apple celebrated the 10 billionth song downloaded from the iTunes Music Store.[[176]](#cite_note-176)

### Intel transition

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Intel transition")]

Main article: [Mac transition to Intel processors](/wiki/Mac_transition_to_Intel_processors "Mac transition to Intel processors")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/MacBook_Pro.png/250px-MacBook_Pro.png)](/wiki/File:MacBook_Pro.png)

[MacBook Pro](/wiki/MacBook_Pro "MacBook Pro") Intel-based (2006)

In a keynote address on June 6, 2005, Jobs announced that Apple would produce Intel-based Macintosh computers beginning in 2006.[[177]](#cite_note-177) Jobs confirmed rumors that the company had been secretly producing versions of [Mac OS X](/wiki/MacOS "MacOS") for both PowerPC and Intel processors over the past 5 years, and that the transition to Intel processor systems would last until the end of 2007. Rumors of cross-platform compatibility had been spurred by the fact that Mac OS X is based on [OPENSTEP](/wiki/OPENSTEP "OPENSTEP"), an operating system that was available for many platforms. Apple's own [Darwin](/wiki/Darwin_(operating_system) "Darwin (operating system)"), the [open source](/wiki/Open-source_software "Open-source software") underpinnings of Mac OS X, was also available for Intel's x86 architecture.[[178]](#cite_note-178)[[179]](#cite_note-179)[[180]](#cite_note-180)

On January 10, 2006, the Intel-based [iMac](/wiki/IMac "IMac") and [MacBook Pro](/wiki/MacBook_Pro "MacBook Pro") were introduced,[[181]](#cite_note-181)[[182]](#cite_note-182) based on the [Intel Core](/wiki/Intel_Core "Intel Core") Duo platform. They came alongside news that Apple would complete the transition to Intel processors on all hardware by the end of 2006, a year ahead of the originally quoted schedule.

## 2007–2011: Apple Inc., iPhone, iOS, iPad

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: 2007–2011: Apple Inc., iPhone, iOS, iPad")]

On January 9, 2007, Apple Computer, Inc. shortened its name to simply Apple Inc. In his [Macworld Expo](/wiki/Macworld_Expo "Macworld Expo") keynote address, Jobs explained that with their current product mix consisting of the iPod and Apple TV as well as their Macintosh brand, Apple really wasn't just a computer company anymore. At the same address, Jobs revealed a product that would revolutionize an industry in which Apple had never previously competed: the Apple [iPhone](/wiki/IPhone "IPhone"). The iPhone combined Apple's first widescreen iPod with the world's first mobile device boasting visual voicemail, and an internet communicator able to run a fully-functional version of Apple's web browser, [Safari](/wiki/Safari_(web_browser) "Safari (web browser)"), on the then-named [iPhone OS](/wiki/IOS_version_history#Releases "IOS version history") (later renamed [iOS](/wiki/IOS "IOS")).

### iOS evolution: iPhone and iPad

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: iOS evolution: iPhone and iPad")]

Main articles: [iOS](/wiki/IOS "IOS"), [iPhone](/wiki/IPhone "IPhone"), and [iPad](/wiki/IPad "IPad")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/IPhone_First_Generation.jpg/250px-IPhone_First_Generation.jpg)](/wiki/File:IPhone_First_Generation.jpg)

The original [iPhone](/wiki/IPhone_(1st_generation) "IPhone (1st generation)") (2007)

The first version of the iPhone became publicly available on June 29, 2007, in selected countries/markets. It was another 12 months before the [iPhone 3G](/wiki/IPhone_3G "IPhone 3G") became available on July 11, 2008. Apple announced the [iPhone 3GS](/wiki/IPhone_3GS "IPhone 3GS") on June 8, 2009, along with plans to release it later in June, July, and August, starting with the U.S., Canada, and major European countries on June 19. This 12-month iteration cycle has continued with the [iPhone 4](/wiki/IPhone_4 "IPhone 4") model arriving in similar fashion in 2010, a Verizon model was released in February 2011, and a Sprint model in October 2011, shortly after Jobs' death.

On February 10, 2011, the iPhone 4 was made available on both Verizon Wireless and AT&T. Now two iPod types are multi-touch: the iPod nano and the iPod touch, a big advance in technology. Apple TV currently has a 2nd-generation model, which is 4 times smaller than the original Apple TV. Apple has also gone wireless, selling a wireless trackpad, keyboard, mouse, and external hard drive. Wired accessories are still available.

The Apple [iPad](/wiki/IPad "IPad") was announced on January 27, 2010, with retail availability commencing in April and systematically growing in markets throughout 2010. The iPad fits into Apple's iOS product line, being twice the screen size of an iPhone without the phone abilities. While there were initial fears of product cannibalization the FY2010 financial results released in Jan 2011 included commentary of a reverse 'halo' effect, where iPad sales were leading to increased sales of iMacs and MacBooks.[[183]](#cite_note-183)

### Resurgence compared to Microsoft

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Resurgence compared to Microsoft")]

Since 2005, Apple's revenues, profits, and stock price have grown significantly. On May 26, 2010, Apple's stock market value overtook Microsoft's,[[184]](#cite_note-184)[[185]](#cite_note-185)[[186]](#cite_note-186) and Apple's revenues surpassed those of Microsoft in the third quarter of 2010.[[187]](#cite_note-187)[[188]](#cite_note-188) After giving their results for the first quarter of 2011, Microsoft's net profits of $5.2 billion were lower for the quarter than those of Apple, which earned $6 billion in net profit for the quarter.[[189]](#cite_note-Apple_Microsoft_revenue-189)[[190]](#cite_note-190) The late April announcement of profits by the companies marked the first time in 20 years that Microsoft's profits had been lower than Apple's,[[191]](#cite_note-Apple_Microsoft_20_years-191) a situation described by *[Ars Technica](/wiki/Ars_Technica "Ars Technica")* as "unimaginable a decade ago".[[189]](#cite_note-Apple_Microsoft_revenue-189)

*[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")* reported that one of the reasons for the change was because PC software, where Microsoft dominates, has become less important compared to the tablet and smartphone markets, where Apple has a strong presence.[[191]](#cite_note-Apple_Microsoft_20_years-191) One reason for this was a surprise drop in PC sales in the quarter.[[191]](#cite_note-Apple_Microsoft_20_years-191) Another issue for Microsoft was that its online search business had lost a lot of money, with a loss of $700 million in the first quarter of 2010.[[191]](#cite_note-Apple_Microsoft_20_years-191)

## 2011–2020: Restructuring and Apple Watch

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: 2011–2020: Restructuring and Apple Watch")]

See also: [Apple car project](/wiki/Apple_car_project "Apple car project")

On March 2, 2011, Apple unveiled the iPad's second-generation model, the [iPad 2](/wiki/IPad_2 "IPad 2"). Like the 4th-generation iPod Touch and iPhone, the iPad 2 comes with a front-facing camera as well as a rear-facing camera, along with three new apps that utilize these new features: Camera, [FaceTime](/wiki/FaceTime "FaceTime"), and [Photo Booth](/wiki/Photo_Booth "Photo Booth"). On August 24, Jobs resigned from his position as CEO,[[192]](#cite_note-192) with Tim Cook taking his place.

On October 29, 2012, Apple announced structural changes to increase collaboration between hardware, software, and services.[[193]](#cite_note-193) This involved the departure of [Scott Forstall](/wiki/Scott_Forstall "Scott Forstall"), responsible for the launch of iOS (iPhone OS at the time of launch), who was replaced with [Craig Federighi](/wiki/Craig_Federighi "Craig Federighi") as head of iOS and OS X teams. [Jony Ive](/wiki/Jony_Ive "Jony Ive") became head of HI (Human Interface), whilst [Eddy Cue](/wiki/Eddy_Cue "Eddy Cue") was announced as head of online services including Siri and Maps. The most notable short term difference of this restructuring was the launch of [iOS 7](/wiki/IOS_7 "IOS 7"), the first version of the operating system to use a drastically different design to its predecessors, headed by Jony Ive,[[194]](#cite_note-194) followed by [OS X Yosemite](/wiki/OS_X_Yosemite "OS X Yosemite") a year later with a similar design.
