During this time, Apple released the [iPhone 5](/wiki/IPhone_5 "IPhone 5"), the first iPhone to have a screen larger than 3.5",[[195]](#cite_note-195) the [iPod Touch 5](/wiki/IPod_Touch_5 "IPod Touch 5") with a 4" screen, the [iPhone 5S](/wiki/IPhone_5S "IPhone 5S") with fingerprint scanning technology in the form of [Touch ID](/wiki/Touch_ID "Touch ID"), and [iPhone 6](/wiki/IPhone_6 "IPhone 6") and [iPhone 6 Plus](/wiki/IPhone_6_Plus "IPhone 6 Plus"), with screens at 4.7" and 5.5". They released the [3rd-generation iPad](/wiki/IPad_(3rd_generation) "IPad (3rd generation)") with Retina Display, followed by the [4th-generation iPad](/wiki/IPad_(4th_generation) "IPad (4th generation)") just half a year later. The [iPad Mini](/wiki/IPad_Mini "IPad Mini") was announced alongside the iPad 4th gen, and was the first to feature a smaller screen than 9.7". This was followed by the [iPad Mini 2](/wiki/IPad_Mini_2 "IPad Mini 2") with Retina Display in 2013, alongside the [iPad Air](/wiki/IPad_Air "IPad Air"), a continuation of the original 9.7" range of iPads, which was subsequently followed by the [iPad Air 2](/wiki/IPad_Air_2 "IPad Air 2") with Touch ID in 2014. Apple released various major Mac updates, including the [MacBook Pro with Retina Display](/wiki/MacBook_Pro_with_Retina_Display "MacBook Pro with Retina Display"),[[196]](#cite_note-196) whilst discontinuing the original [MacBook](/wiki/MacBook "MacBook") range for a short period, before reintroducing it in 2015 with various new features, a Retina Display and a new design that implemented [USB-C](/wiki/USB-C "USB-C"), while removing all other ports.[[197]](#cite_note-197) The [Mac Pro](/wiki/Mac_Pro "Mac Pro") and [iMac](/wiki/IMac "IMac") were updated with more power and a drastically smaller and thinner profile. On November 25, 2013, Apple acquired a company called PrimeSense.[[198]](#cite_note-198)

On May 28, 2014, Apple acquired [Beats Electronics](/wiki/Beats_Electronics "Beats Electronics"), producers of the popular [Beats by Dre](/wiki/Beats_by_Dre "Beats by Dre") headphone and speaker range, as well as streaming service [Beats Music](/wiki/Beats_Music "Beats Music"). On September 9, 2014, Apple announced the [Apple Watch](/wiki/Apple_Watch "Apple Watch"), the first new product range since the departure of Jobs.[[199]](#cite_note-199) The product cannot function beyond basic features without being within Bluetooth or WiFi range to an iPhone and contains basic applications (many acting as a remote for other devices, such as a music remote, or a control for an Apple TV) and fitness tracking. The Apple Watch received mixed reviews, with critics suggesting that whilst the device showed promise, it lacked a clear purpose, similar to many of the devices already on the market.[[200]](#cite_note-200) The Apple Watch was released on April 24, 2015.[[201]](#cite_note-201)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Apple_Watch_Demo.jpg/250px-Apple_Watch_Demo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Watch_Demo.jpg)

[Apple Watch](/wiki/Apple_Watch "Apple Watch") first generation (2015)

On September 9, 2015, Apple announced the [iPhone 6S](/wiki/IPhone_6S "IPhone 6S") and [iPhone 6S Plus](/wiki/IPhone_6S_Plus "IPhone 6S Plus") with 3D Touch, the [iPad Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro"), and the fourth-generation [Apple TV](/wiki/Apple_TV "Apple TV"), along with the fourth-generation [iPad Mini](/wiki/IPad_Mini "IPad Mini").
On March 21, 2016, Apple announced the [first-generation iPhone SE](/wiki/IPhone_SE_(1st_generation) "IPhone SE (1st generation)") and the smaller [iPad Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro").

On September 7, 2016, Apple announced the [iPhone 7](/wiki/IPhone_7 "IPhone 7") and [iPhone 7 Plus](/wiki/IPhone_7_Plus "IPhone 7 Plus") with an improved camera and a faster processor than the previous generation. The iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus have high storage options.
On October 27, 2016, Apple announced the new 13 and 15 inch [MacBook Pro](/wiki/MacBook_Pro "MacBook Pro") with a retina Touch Bar.
On March 21, 2017, Apple announced the [iPad (2017)](/wiki/IPad_(2017) "IPad (2017)"). This is the iPad Air 2 successor, equipped with a faster processor, and starts at $329. Apple also announced the (Product)RED iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus.

On June 5, 2017, Apple announced [iOS 11](/wiki/IOS_11 "IOS 11") as well as new versions of [macOS](/wiki/MacOS "MacOS"), [watchOS](/wiki/WatchOS "WatchOS"), and [tvOS](/wiki/TvOS "TvOS"). Updated versions of the iMac, MacBook Pro, and MacBook were released, along with the 10.5 and 12.9 inch [iPad Pro](/wiki/IPad_Pro "IPad Pro"), and "[HomePod](/wiki/HomePod "HomePod")", a Siri speaker similar to the [Amazon Echo](/wiki/Amazon_Echo "Amazon Echo"). On September 12, at the [Steve Jobs Theater](/wiki/Steve_Jobs_Theater "Steve Jobs Theater"), Apple introduced the [iPhone 8](/wiki/IPhone_8 "IPhone 8") and iPhone 8 Plus with better camera features, more improvements in [product design](/wiki/Product_design "Product design"), [user experience](/wiki/User_experience "User experience"), performance and more, and announced the [iPhone X](/wiki/IPhone_X "IPhone X") with facial recognition technology and wireless charging. Apple announced the 4K Apple TV with 4K, HDR and Dolby Vision experience, and the Apple Watch Series 3, supporting a cellular connection, running [watchOS 4](/wiki/WatchOS "WatchOS").

In March 2018, [*Bloomberg*](/wiki/Bloomberg_News "Bloomberg News") reported that Apple was developing [MicroLED](/wiki/MicroLED "MicroLED") screens for the iPhone, iPad, Mac, watch, AR glasses, and [electric car](/wiki/Apple_car_project "Apple car project").[[202]](#cite_note-202)[[203]](#cite_note-203)[[204]](#cite_note-204) It was linked to a Research and Development facility in [Santa Clara, California](/wiki/Santa_Clara,_California "Santa Clara, California") code named Aria[[205]](#cite_note-205) by the *Bay Area News Group*.[[206]](#cite_note-206) On September 12, at the [Steve Jobs Theater](/wiki/Steve_Jobs_Theater "Steve Jobs Theater"), Apple introduced the [iPhone XS](/wiki/IPhone_XS "IPhone XS"), [iPhone XS Max](/wiki/IPhone_XS "IPhone XS"), and [iPhone XR](/wiki/IPhone_XR "IPhone XR"), running [iOS 12](/wiki/IOS_12 "IOS 12"), with improved facial recognition and HDR in the display as well as better cameras for all 3 phones. They also announced the Apple Watch Series 4, running [watchOS 5](/wiki/WatchOS "WatchOS"), with an all-new design and larger display as well as many more health-related features.

In October 2018, *Bloomberg* reported that, as early as 2015, a specialized unit of China's [People's Liberation Army](/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army "People's Liberation Army") began inserting chips into [Supermicro](/wiki/Supermicro "Supermicro") servers that allowed for [backdoor](/wiki/Backdoor_(computing) "Backdoor (computing)") access to them.[[207]](#cite_note-BB-207) Approximately 30 companies reportedly had their servers compromised via the chips, including Apple Inc.[[207]](#cite_note-BB-207) On September 20, 2019, the [iPhone 11](/wiki/IPhone_11 "IPhone 11"), [iPhone 11 Pro](/wiki/IPhone_11_Pro "IPhone 11 Pro"), and iPhone 11 Pro Max were introduced. The iPhone 11 Pro was the first iPhone to feature three cameras.

## 2020–present: 5G and Apple silicon

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: 2020–present: 5G and Apple silicon")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png/250px-Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png)](/wiki/File:Macbook_Air_M1_Silver_PNG.png)

[MacBook Air M1](/wiki/MacBook_Air_(Apple_silicon) "MacBook Air (Apple silicon)") (2020)

In 2020, Apple was fined £21 million euros, claiming they intentionally [slowed down older models](/wiki/Planned_obsolescence "Planned obsolescence") of iPhones to encourage people to buy newer models. The company somewhat admitted to this practice in 2017, saying the phones were slowed to respond to the [decay](/wiki/Capacity_loss "Capacity loss") of iPhones' [lithium-ion batteries](/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery "Lithium-ion battery"), which made it harder for the batteries to reach the phones' expected power demands.[[208]](#cite_note-208) The [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic") heavily effected China, hurting Apple financially, because they invested into China enough to become increasingly dependent on the country.[[209]](#cite_note-O'Flaherty-209) Chinese factories closed and demand for Apple products went down.[[210]](#cite_note-210) However, they recovered and eventually reached a US$2 trillion market cap later that year.[[211]](#cite_note-211) The [iPhone 12](/wiki/IPhone_12 "IPhone 12"), [12 Pro, and 12 Pro Max](/wiki/IPhone_12_Pro "IPhone 12 Pro") were introduced, being the first iPhones to support [5G](/wiki/5G "5G") connectivity.[[212]](#cite_note-212) The company also started using its own [Apple silicon](/wiki/Apple_silicon "Apple silicon") processors in Macs, instead of chips made by Intel.[[213]](#cite_note-213)[[214]](#cite_note-214)

In April 2021, the M1-powered iPad was launched, along with a new M1-powered iMac offered in 7 colors, recalling the [iMacs offered in 5 colors](/wiki/IMac_G3#Model_line-up "IMac G3") announced in 1999. Apple launched a GPS tracking device called [AirTag](/wiki/AirTag "AirTag") that uses the Apple's [Find My](/wiki/Find_My "Find My") device network. In 2021 and 2022, Apple repeated its pattern of introducing four new iPhones in September, with 2021's [iPhone 13](/wiki/IPhone_13 "IPhone 13") and [iPhone 13 Pro](/wiki/IPhone_13_Pro "IPhone 13 Pro") lines and 2022's [iPhone 14](/wiki/IPhone_14 "IPhone 14") and [iPhone 14 Pro](/wiki/IPhone_14_Pro "IPhone 14 Pro") lines. The iPhone 14 Pro ditched the [notch](/wiki/Notch_(engineering) "Notch (engineering)") containing the sensors for a "dynamic island", which allows for space between the top edge of the screen and the sensors for Face ID. 2022 saw Apple announce the first Macs with Apple's [M2](/wiki/Apple_M2 "Apple M2") chip and a new sub-series of Apple Watch with increased performance for outdoor activities named [Apple Watch Ultra](/wiki/Apple_Watch_Ultra "Apple Watch Ultra").

Apple experienced a period of unprecedented employee unrest in 2021 and 2022, resulting in outspoken employees organizing over labor issues and the company's treatment of women at the company in its corporate offices and retail stores.[[215]](#cite_note-:3-215)[[216]](#cite_note-216) Employees engaged in [hashtag activism](/wiki/Hashtag_activism "Hashtag activism") on social media inspired by the [#MeToo movement](/wiki/MeToo_movement "MeToo movement") called [#AppleToo](/wiki/AppleToo "AppleToo")[[217]](#cite_note-217) and two American stores [unionized](/wiki/Apple_Inc._and_unions "Apple Inc. and unions") for the first time.[[218]](#cite_note-218)

In 2022, Apple paused all product sales in Russia in response to the country's [invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine").[[219]](#cite_note-219) Tim Cook began focusing on privacy features, which lowered App Store developers' revenue. They also developed App Tracking Transparency, a set of privacy features which cost Facebook US$12 billion.[[209]](#cite_note-O'Flaherty-209) The company also announced they would start including ads in the Books, Maps, and TV iOS apps,[[220]](#cite_note-220) and that it would eventually move production out of China.[[221]](#cite_note-221)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Apple_Vision_Pro_on_display.jpg/250px-Apple_Vision_Pro_on_display.jpg)](/wiki/File:Apple_Vision_Pro_on_display.jpg)

An [Apple Vision Pro](/wiki/Apple_Vision_Pro "Apple Vision Pro") headset on display

Apple launched a [buy now, pay later](/wiki/Buy_now,_pay_later "Buy now, pay later") service called 'Apple Pay Later' for its [Apple Wallet](/wiki/Apple_Wallet "Apple Wallet") users in 2023. The program allows its users to apply for loans between $50 and $1,000 to make online or in-app purchases, and then repaying them through four installments spread over six weeks without any interest or fees.[[222]](#cite_note-222)[[223]](#cite_note-223) In June, Apple released the [Apple Vision Pro](/wiki/Apple_Vision_Pro "Apple Vision Pro"), a computer in the form of an [augmented reality](/wiki/Augmented_reality "Augmented reality") headset which runs the [VisionOS](/wiki/VisionOS "VisionOS") operating system. Wearers of the headset use hand gestures to navigate the user interface.[[224]](#cite_note-224) It initially released at $3,500 in the United States, and while sales figures have not been released as of June 2024, it is considered to be a financial failure in its initial stages.[[225]](#cite_note-225) The company then reached a $25 million settlement in a [U.S. Department of Justice](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department of Justice") case that alleged they were discriminating against U.S. citizens in hiring; they created jobs that were not listed online and required paper submission to apply for, while advertising these jobs to foreign workers as part of recruitment for [PERM](/wiki/Permanent_Labor_Certification#Program_electronic_review_management "Permanent Labor Certification").[[226]](#cite_note-226)

In April 2024, Apple laid off more than 600 employees working in facilities linked to the electric car project and microLED development.[[227]](#cite_note-227) The projects had been reported to have been shut down in the preceding two months.[[228]](#cite_note-228)[[229]](#cite_note-229)

In June 2024, Apple announced [iOS18](/wiki/IOS_18 "IOS 18") and [macOS Sequoia](/wiki/MacOS_Sequoia "MacOS Sequoia") in their [WWDC](/wiki/Worldwide_Developers_Conference "Worldwide Developers Conference") 2024 event.[[230]](#cite_note-230)[[231]](#cite_note-231) After the development of powerful [AI](/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") software like [OpenAI](/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI")'s [ChatGPT](/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") in the early 2020s, Apple was accused of being behind their competitors in innovating using AI;[[232]](#cite_note-232) alongside the new operating systems, the company announced they would introduce AI features into their products, such as using ChatGPT to improve Siri. The first product to feature these improvements, named [Apple Intelligence](/wiki/Apple_Intelligence "Apple Intelligence"), is planned to be the [iPhone 15 Pro](/wiki/IPhone_15_Pro "IPhone 15 Pro") running iOS 18.[[233]](#cite_note-233) Criticism was leveled towards the plan to incorporate recorded user inputs into ChatGPT's [data set](/wiki/Data_set "Data set").[[234]](#cite_note-234) Apple did not pay OpenAI for these features, believing that exposure to OpenAI products will already financially benefit them.[[235]](#cite_note-235) The announcement improved Apple's stock, temporarily making them the world's most valuable company instead of Microsoft.[[236]](#cite_note-236)

In 2024, Apple was sued by two female employees seeking class action who claimed that the company's hiring and performance-review practices are biased against women.[[237]](#cite_note-237) Meanwhile, the [National Labor Relations Board](/wiki/National_Labor_Relations_Board "National Labor Relations Board") (NLRB) charged Apple with violations of the [National Labor Relations Act of 1935](/wiki/National_Labor_Relations_Act_of_1935 "National Labor Relations Act of 1935") in spring and fall of 2024. The NLRB accused Apple of maintaining unlawful employee contracts, rules around social media and [Slack](/wiki/Slack_(software) "Slack (software)") usage, for interrogating unionizing employees, and for illegally firing [Janneke Parrish](/wiki/Janneke_Parrish "Janneke Parrish"), a labor activist who had co-lead the #AppleToo movement.[[238]](#cite_note-238)[[239]](#cite_note-239)[[240]](#cite_note-240)

### Stock

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Apple_Inc.&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Stock")]

'AAPL' is the [stock symbol](/wiki/Stock_symbol "Stock symbol") under which [Apple Inc.](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") trades on the [NASDAQ](/wiki/NASDAQ "NASDAQ") [stock market](/wiki/Stock_market "Stock market"). Apple originally went public on December 12, 1980, with an [initial public offering](/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering") at US$22.00[[245]](#cite_note-245) per share. The stock has split 2 for 1 three times on June 15, 1987, June 21, 2000, and February 28, 2005. Apple initially paid dividends from June 15, 1987, to December 15, 1995. On March 19, 2012, Apple announced that it would again start paying a dividend of $2.65 per quarter (beginning in the quarter that starts in July 2012) along a $10 billion [share buyback](/wiki/Share_repurchase "Share repurchase") that would commence September 30, 2012, the start of its fiscal 2013 year. Gene Munster and Michael Olson of [Piper Jaffray](/wiki/Piper_Jaffray "Piper Jaffray") are the main analysts who track Apple stock. Piper Jaffray estimates future stock and revenue of Apple annually, and have been doing so for several years.[[246]](#cite_note-246)

results.content:
Follow:
    is an American computer and consumer electronics company famous for creating the iPhone, iPad and Macintosh computers. Apple is one of the largest companies globally with a market cap of more than $3 trillion.

Apple devices are renowned for their design aesthetic and attention to detail. Tight integration between hardware and software gives their systems a performance advantage over competitor systems with similar specifications. [...] Image 4: Photo of Apple iPhone 14 Pro and Max

The iPhone 14 Pro and Max 

Apple Inc. history
------------------

Apple Computer was founded in 1976 by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak. The third founding member, Ronald Wayne, quickly sold his ownership to Jobs and Wozniak. Their first product was the Apple I microcomputer, which they built in Jobs' family garage. It was sold as a single board with CPU and RAM, but without other basic components such as a keyboard and monitor. [...] iPhone and iPad. The iPhone is Apple's smartphone line, and the iPad is its tablet. The iPhone was the first smartphone to receive mass market adoption due to its ease of use, built-in app store and capacitive multitouch touchscreen. The iPhone uses the "A" series mobile CPU, and recent iPads use the same "M" series CPUs as Mac computers. Their operating systems iOS and iPadOS, are based on the same Unix kernel as macOS but have a touch-focused interface.

Definition
Apple
=====

*   Share this item with your network:
*   [](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple#)
*   [](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple#)

*       *   [](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple#)
    *   [](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple#)
    *   [](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple#)
    *   [](mailto:?subject=What%20is%20Apple?%20An%20products%20and%20history%20overview&body=https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple)

![Image 1: Gavin Wright](https://cdn.ttgtmedia.com/rms/onlineimages/wright_gavin.jpg)

By
*   [Gavin Wright](https://www.techtarget.com/contributor/Gavin-Wright)

 Published: Sep 11, 2024

What is Apple?
--------------

Apple Inc. (formerly Apple Computer Inc.) is an American computer and consumer electronics company famous for creating the iPhone, iPad and Macintosh computers. Apple is one of the largest companies globally with a market cap of more than $3 trillion.

Apple devices are renowned for their design aesthetic and attention to detail. Tight integration between [hardware](https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/hardware) and [software](https://www.techtarget.com/searchapparchitecture/definition/software) gives their [systems](https://www.techtarget.com/searchwindowsserver/definition/system) a performance advantage over competitor systems with similar specifications.

Apple rose to its position as a market leader by correctly positioning its products. They didn't invent [personal computers](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/personal-computer-PC), graphical user interfaces (GUIs), [mp3](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/MP3-MPEG-1-Audio-Layer-3) players, [smartphones](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/smartphone), [smartwatches](https://www.techtarget.com/iotagenda/definition/smartwatch) or [tablets](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/tablet-PC). Instead, they produced some of the first versions of these products that were refined, easy to use and well-designed, which led to wide market adoption.

![Image 2: Photo of Apple devices](https://www.techtarget.com/rms/onlineImages/access_0318-apple_products_mobile.png)

Apple desktop and mobile devices 

Apple product lines
-------------------

Apple offers numerous products and services. A few of its major offerings today include:

**Mac computer****.** The [Macintosh](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Macintosh), or Mac, is Apple's line of personal computers. Its main product types are the iMac all-in-one desktop, Mac mini standard desktop, Mac Studio media-focused desktop, Mac Pro professional production workstation desktop, MacBook Air consumer laptop and MacBook Pro professional laptop.

![Image 3: Photo of MacBook Air](https://www.techtarget.com/rms/onlineimages/macbook_air_m2-f_mobile.jpg)

MacBook Air laptop 

All Mac computers use the [macOS](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Mac-OS) operating system. Since 2020, they use the "M" series CPUs designed by Apple based on [ARM](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/ARM-processor) architecture. These chips have been praised for their excellent performance and power efficiency. Mac computers are popular with students and creative professionals for their elevated style and ease of use. Computer programmers might also use them because the underlying operating system is based on Unix and is [POSIX](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/POSIX-Portable-Operating-System-Interface) compatible. Due to the lack of built-in central management and high cost, Mac computers have historically been unpopular in the workplace. Still, the introduction of [Zero Trust](https://www.techtarget.com/searchsecurity/definition/zero-trust-model-zero-trust-network), [BYOD](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/BYOD-bring-your-own-device) and third-party tools such as [Jamf](https://www.techtarget.com/searchenterprisedesktop/tip/Explore-Jamfs-products-and-features-for-Apple-management) have begun to make them more acceptable to IT administrators.

**iPhone and iPad.** The [iPhone](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/iPhone) is Apple's smartphone line, and the [iPad](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/iPad) is its tablet. The iPhone was the first smartphone to receive mass market adoption due to its ease of use, built-in app store and [capacitive](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/capacitive-touch-screen) multitouch touchscreen. The iPhone uses the "A" series mobile CPU, and recent iPads use the same "M" series CPUs as Mac computers. Their operating systems [iOS](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/iOS) and iPadOS, are based on the same Unix kernel as macOS but have a touch-focused interface.

**Apple Watch.**The[Apple Watch](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/Apple-Watch)is a smartwatch and fitness tracker. It can monitor health signals, such as ECG, blood oxygen and heart rate data. It can also act as a digital key, allowing users to unlock, lock and start compatible cars. The Apple Watch runs on the[watchOS](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/Apple-Watch-OS-Apple-Watch-operating-system) operating system.

**Apple AirPods.**AirPods are wireless headphones that sync with Apple devices through Bluetooth. Apple users can listen to audio including music, movies and messages through AirPods. Additionally, users can take phone calls through AirPods and use Siri. The AirPods Pro 2 can be used as an over-the-counter hearing aid for those who do not suffer from severe hearing loss, but to use this feature, users need to take a test to analyze hearing loss.

**Apple TV.**[Apple TV](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/Apple-TV-Apple-TV-4)is a television set-top box and streaming media device. AppleTV has voice control capabilities and can integrate with other Apple devices via Airplay. It also has video conferencing features and the ability to locate the Siri remote. The Apple TV runs on the [tvOS](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/tvOS) operating system.

**Apple Airtag.**The Apple Airtag is a small tracking device. Users can attach it to items they wish to track and see its location using the Find My app. The Airtag uses Bluetooth to establish its location by communicating with other devices in the Find My network.

**Vision Pro.**The Apple Vision Pro is a[mixed reality](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/mixed-reality)headset -- an augmented reality headset also capable of virtual reality. It was[debuted at WWDC](https://www.computerweekly.com/news/366539415/Apples-3500-headset-offers-VR-at-a-premium)– Apple's annual developers conference -- in 2023, and it became available in all U.S. Apple Store locations and the Apple Store online on Feb. 2, 2024. It runs on the visionOS operating system, which displays apps using[spatial computing](https://www.techtarget.com/searchcio/definition/spatial-computing). The user interface is controlled by eyes, hands and voice. Users can video conference, stream media and capture images using a three-dimensional camera. The headset has advanced eye tracking and optical identity features – called Optic ID -- for authentication and security. The Vision Pro supports Microsoft Word, Excel and Teams. It is available starting at $3,499, with 256GB of storage. Zeiss optical inserts are also available for this headset, at $99 for readers and $149 for prescriptions.

**Services.** Apple also provides several services that seamlessly work with its products. Apple [iCloud](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/iCloud) is a personal file storage and synchronization service. Apple Pay is a money payment system and a credit card provider. Apple TV+ is a media streaming service with movies and TV programming. Apple also provides other media under the iTunes store, Apple Music, Apple Books and other services. iMessage is an Apple device-specific instant messaging service that extends [SMS](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/Short-Message-Service) for iPhones. [Siri](https://www.techtarget.com/searchmobilecomputing/definition/Siri) is a virtual assistant that answers questions and performs various tasks, such as making phone calls or sending messages.

**Apple Intelligence.**Apple created its AI platform for [generative AI](https://www.techtarget.com/searchenterpriseai/definition/generative-AI) capabilities across its products. [Apple Intelligence](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Apple-Intelligence) integrates ChatGPT through Siri for more advanced answers. Users can use Apple Intelligence to manage schedules, enhance writing, summarize text from emails or messages, create custom emojis or images, enhance photos and create memory movies. Apple Intelligence will be integrated into iOS 18 and supported on devices such as iPhone 15 Pro and newer; iPad Air models with M1 or newer chips; and Mac models with M1 or newer chips.

![Image 4: Photo of Apple iPhone 14 Pro and Max](https://www.techtarget.com/rms/onlineimages/Apple_iPhone_14_Pro_iPhone_14_Pro_Max_Dynamic_Island_demo_3up_mobile.jpg)

The iPhone 14 Pro and Max 

Apple Inc. history
------------------

Apple Computer was founded in 1976 by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak. The third founding member, Ronald Wayne, quickly sold his ownership to Jobs and Wozniak. Their first product was the Apple I [microcomputer](https://www.techtarget.com/iotagenda/definition/microcomputer), which they built in Jobs' family garage. It was sold as a single board with [CPU](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/processor) and [RAM](https://www.techtarget.com/searchstorage/definition/RAM-random-access-memory), but without other basic components such as a keyboard and monitor.

The Apple II was introduced in 1977. It was a commercial success due to its ease of use, color graphics and VisiCalc, a spreadsheet program. Its popularity propelled Apple to become the leading computer manufacturer in America and led to one of the largest IPOs of its time.

Steve Jobs became obsessed with GUIs after seeing Xerox's early Alto system. This led him to add a GUI to the next Apple system, the Apple Lisa. Under Jobs' direction, the Apple Lisa development went far over time and over budget, which led to his being removed as the head of the project. The Apple Lisa was eventually released in 1983 but was a commercial flop due to its high price and lack of software.

Jobs moved to head development of the Macintosh computer. An advertisement heralded its release in 1984 during the Super Bowl with a dystopian 1984 theme, which was a direct challenge to the market leader [IBM](https://www.techtarget.com/searchitchannel/definition/IBM-International-Business-Machines). This advertisement is widely considered one of the greatest ads ever shown on television. Despite this, the Macintosh had poor initial sales due to its high price and low performance.

![Image 5: Photo of Apple iPad series of tablets](https://www.techtarget.com/rms/onlineimages/apple_ipad_air_availability_ipad_family_10162020_half_column_mobile.jpg)

Apple iPad series 

The conflict between Steve Jobs and then Apple CEO John Sculley over the release of the Macintosh led to Jobs being removed from all duties by the board of directors. This caused Jobs to leave Apple and start a new company, NeXT computers. At about this time, Steve Wozniak also stepped down from a leadership role at Apple due to personal reasons.

Despite the loss of its founding members, Apple continued to do well in the late 1980s and early 1990s. This was largely due to continuing sales of the Apple II and the eventual success of an upgraded Macintosh in the creative market. During this time, Adobe products, such as [Photoshop](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/Photoshop) and Publisher, and other high-quality [digital publishing](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/desktop-publishing) software were only available on Macintosh.

Several factors led to Apple losing profitability, and almost going bankrupt in the mid-1990s. Apple experimented with releasing other consumer electronics products. The most disastrous of which was the Newton tablet. Apple also faced stiff competition from lower-cost Microsoft Windows-based PCs, especially with the release of [Windows](https://www.techtarget.com/searchwindowsserver/definition/Windows) 95. The Macintosh operating system was also starting to show its age and did not properly support Multitasking.

Desperate to return to profitability and find a new operating system for its computers, Apple purchased Steve Jobs' new company, NeXT in early 1997. Jobs was then named interim CEO of Apple after the former CEO was ousted in mid-1997. He was able to refocus Apple on its core computer business and save it from bankruptcy. In 1998 the iMac was introduced. It was designed by Jonathan Ive and was popular for its friendly colorful gumdrop shape. Apple also introduced video editing and CD/DVD mastering software, cementing Macintosh's role in digital media production.

Mac OS X was released in 2001. It was based on the operating system work of NeXT and used the stable and secure BSD Unix [kernel](https://www.techtarget.com/searchdatacenter/definition/kernel). Also, in 2001, Apple released the iPod to wide acclaim, establishing Apple's place as a trendsetter in consumer electronics.

The iPhone was introduced in 2007, becoming one of the first popular smartphones. The next year App Store launched, allowing third-party developers to sell and market their apps to users. The iPhone was followed by the popular iPhone 4 and iPad in 2010.

![Image 6: Chart of Apple's iPhone evolution](https://www.techtarget.com/rms/onlineimages/evolution_of_apple_iphone-f_mobile.png)

Evolution of the Apple iPhone 

In early 2011 Steve Jobs took a leave of absence; naming Tim Cook as the new CEO of Apple. Steve Jobs died on October 5, 2011.

Apple has continued to release new products and expanded services in recent years. Apple has switched to using its own in-house designed CPUs, first in iPhone and now in its Macintosh line of computers. It also offers media [streaming services](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/video-streaming-service) through Apple TV+ and Apple Music. It is expected that Apple might enter new markets soon, with rumors that a [virtual reality](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/virtual-reality)/[augmented reality](https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/augmented-reality-AR) headset and a [self-driving automobile](https://www.techtarget.com/searchenterpriseai/definition/driverless-car) in development.

Apple, Inc. engages in the design, manufacture, and sale of smartphones, personal computers, tablets, wearables and accessories, and other variety of related services. It operates through the following geographical segments: Americas, Europe, Greater China, Japan, and Rest of Asia Pacific. The Americas segment includes North and South America. The Europe segment consists of European countries, as well as India, the Middle East, and Africa. The Greater China segment comprises of China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. The Rest of Asia Pacific segment includes Australia and Asian countries. Its products and services include iPhone, Mac, iPad, AirPods, Apple TV, Apple Watch, Beats products, Apple Care, iCloud, digital content stores, streaming, and licensing services. The company was founded by Steven Paul Jobs, Ronald Gerald Wayne, and Stephen G. Wozniak on April 1, 1976 and is headquartered in Cupertino, CA. Read Less

# This Month in Business History

## Business Reference: [Ask a Librarian](https://ask.loc.gov/business "Ask a Librarian")

![](https://cdn.loc.gov/libguide/images/ask-a-librarian-logo.svg)

Have a question? Need assistance? Use our [**online form**](https://ask.loc.gov/business) to ask a librarian for help.

**Author:**  
Angelique Richardson, Intern, *Science, Technology & Business Division*

**Editors:**  
Ellen Terrell, *Business Reference Specialist, Science, Technology & Business Division*

Gulnar Nagashybayeva, *Business Reference Specialist, Science, Technology & Business Division*

**Created:** April 2008

**Last Updated:** April 2023

# The Founding of Apple Computer, Inc.

![](https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/highsm/49100/49193r.jpg)

Apple Computer, Inc. was founded on April 1, 1976, by college dropouts Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, who brought to the new company a vision of changing the way people viewed computers. Jobs and Wozniak wanted to make computers small enough for people to have them in their homes or offices. Simply put, they wanted a computer that was user-friendly.[1](#note1)

Jobs and Wozniak started out building the Apple I in Jobs' garage and sold them without a monitor, keyboard, or casing (which they decided to add on in 1977). The Apple II revolutionized the computer industry with the introduction of the first-ever color graphics. Sales jumped from $7.8 million in 1978 to $117 million in 1980, the year Apple went public.[2](#note2)

Wozniak left Apple in 1983 due to a diminishing interest in the day-to-day running of Apple Computer. Jobs then hired PepsiCo's John Sculley to be president. However, this move backfired and after much controversy with Sculley, Jobs left in 1985 and went on to new and bigger things. He founded his own company NeXT Software and he also bought Pixar from George Lucas, which would later become a huge success in computer animation of such movies as *Toy Story, A Bug's Life, Monsters, Inc.,* and *Finding Nemo.*[3](#note3)

Through the rest of the 1980s, Apple was still doing well and in 1990 it posted its highest profits yet. This was, however, mostly due to the plans that Jobs had already set in motion before he left, most notably his deal with a tiny company by the name of Adobe, creator of the Adobe Portable Document Format (PDF). Together the two companies created the phenomenon known as desktop publishing.[4](#note4)

Back in 1985 Sculley turned down an appeal from Microsoft founder Bill Gates to license its software. This decision would later come back to haunt him because Microsoft, whose Windows operating system (OS) featured a graphical interface similar to Apple's, became their toughest competition in the late 1980s and throughout the 1990s.

Over the course of a few years, Apple's market share suffered slowly after its peak in 1990 and by 1996, experts believed the company to be doomed. It was not until 1997, when Apple was desperately in need of an operating system, that it bought out NeXT Software (Jobs' company) and the board of directors decided to ask for some help from an old friend: Steve Jobs. Jobs became an interim CEO, or iCEO as he called himself (Jobs was not officially the CEO until 2000). Jobs decided to make some changes around Apple. He forged an alliance with Microsoft to create a Mac version of its popular office software. Not long after this decision was the turning point for the company. Jobs revamped the computers and introduced the iBook (a personal laptop) followed by iPod, an mp3 player, which became market leader.

The iPhone, a touch screen cellular phone, introduced in 2007 was one of the world' most successful products and the company has released several new versions since. Not long after the announcement of iPhone and Apple TV, the company dropped "Computer" from its name to become "Apple Inc.," indicating that it is about more than just computers. Other popular products include iPad tablet and Apple Watch. Most recently Apple has expanded its services segments with its credit card (Apple Card), Apple News for news, Apple Arcade for games and the Apple TV+ for streaming original content produced by Apple.[5](#note5) Steve Jobs died October 5, 2011, but Apple continues on with his legacy with Tim Cook at the helm as the CEO. The popularity of iPhones made Apple the first company valued at one trillion dollars in 2018 and two years later it doubled that figure.[6](#note6)

If you have any further questions, please [Ask A Librarian](https://ask.loc.gov/business).

# Apple history

History

## Apple company history timeline

Apple Computer Company was founded on April 1, 1976, by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne as a business partnership.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In July 1976, the Apple 1 went on sale and was sold for $666.66.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 1976 MOS Tech finally released its 6502 chip and Wosniak did not hesitate to write a version of Basic for it.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Their first model was simply a working circuit board, but at Jobs’s insistence the 1977 version was a stand-alone machine in a custom-molded plastic case, in contrast to the forbidding steel boxes of other early machines.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The Apple 1 was sold as a motherboard with CPU, RAM and basic textual-video chips. It then lacked a built-in keyboard, monitor, case or any other Human Interface Devices (which was later added in 1977).

By the end of 1978, Apple was one of the fastest-growing companies in the United States, with its products carried by over 100 dealers.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By 1978 Wozniak had invented the Apple Disk II, at the time the fastest and cheapest disk drive offered by any computer manufacturer.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By the end of the year sales were up 400 percent from 1978, at over 35,000 computers.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Most notably, in 1979 two Bostonians—Dan Bricklin and Bob Frankston—introduced the first personal computer spreadsheet, VisiCalc, creating what would later be known as a “killer app” (application): a software program so useful that it propels hardware sales.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Apple Fortran, introduced in March 1980, led to the further development of software, particularly technical and educational applications.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Apple’s profits and size grew at a historic rate: by 1980 the company netted over $100 million and had more than 1,000 employees.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By the year 1980, the competition was growing difficult with IBM and Microsoft in the market.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

About a year later, in January 1981 to be exact, Apple held its first meeting for shareholders as a public company.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Apples customer service at the time would tell clients to “raise the computer 6 inches in the air and then let go”, in hopes of the components falling back into place. It was finally released in March 1981.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

A second offering of 2.6 million shares quickly sold out in May 1981.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

IBM had waited for the personal computer market to grow before introducing its own line of personal computers, the IBM PC, in 1981.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Wozniak and Raskin had envisioned the Macintosh as low-cost-computer with a text-based interface like the Apple II, but a plane crash in 1981 forced Wozniak to step back from the project.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By January 1982, 650,000 Apple computers had been sold worldwide.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

1982 Apple becomes the first personal computer company to reach $1 billion in annual sales.

The Lisa division would be plagued by infighting, and in 1982 Jobs was pushed off the project.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Wozniak left Apple in 1983 due to a diminishing interest in the day-to-day running of Apple Computers.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Lisa was released in 1983 to much fanfare, but disastrous sales — it was too expensive and didn't have enough software support.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The Lisa launched in 1983 and became the first personal computer sold to the public with a GUI, but was a commercial failure due to its high price and limited software titles.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By the beginning of May 1984, 70,000 units were shipped as a result of the “1984” commercial.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

PageMaker, an early desktop publishing application taking advantage of the PostScript language, was also released by Aldus Corporation in July 1985.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

However, what saved the Mac in those early years was Apple’s 1985 introduction of an affordable laser printer along with Aldus Corporation’s PageMaker, the Mac’s first killer app.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

After the departures of Jobs and Wozniak, Sculley worked to improve the Macintosh in 1985 by quadrupling the RAM and introducing the LaserWriter, the first reasonably priced PostScript laser printer.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Another innovation was a software database called HyperCard, which Apple included free with every Macintosh starting in 1987.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Apple was reorganized in August 1988 into four operating divisions: Apple USA, Apple Europe, Apple Pacific, and Apple Products.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By 1988, over one million Macintosh computers had been sold, with 70 percent of sales to corporations.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In May 1989 Apple announced plans for its new operating system, System 7, which would be available to users the next year and allow Macintoshes to run tasks on more than one program simultaneously.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The Christmas season of 1989 was the first in the company's history to have declining sales, which led to a 20% drop in Apple's stock price.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

During this period, the relationship between Sculley and Gassée deteriorated, leading Sculley to effectively demote Gassée in January 1990 by appointing Michael Spindler as the chief operating officer.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In July 1990, Robert Puette, former head of Hewlett-Packard's personal computer business, became head of the Apple USA division.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The company pivoted strategy and in October 1990 introduced three lower-cost models, the Macintosh Classic, the Macintosh LC, and the Macintosh IIsi, all of which saw significant sales due to pent-up demand.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 1990 the court found in favor of Apple in the Xerox case.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 1990, desktop Macs accounted for 11 percent of the PCs sold through United States computer dealers.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In a rather surprising development, Apple and IBM announced an alliance in 1991.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The bill for such forward-looking surgery was great, however, and in 1991 profits were off 35 percent.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

1991 PowerBook line of notebook computers is released.

In 1991, Apple introduced the hugely successful PowerBook with a design that set the current shape for almost all modern laptops.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Sculley was replaced by Michael Spindler in 1993.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Scully was forced out of his leadership position by Apple's board of directors in 1993.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

After the launch of the LC, Apple began encouraging developers to create applications for Macintosh rather than Apple II, and authorized salespersons to direct consumers towards Macintosh and away from Apple II. The Apple IIe was discontinued in 1993.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The first PowerPC run by Macintosh was released in 1994 but Apple’s misfortune continued.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

With Spindler at the helm Apple, IBM, and Motorola formed the AIM alliance in 1994 with the goal of creating a new computing platform (the PowerPC Reference Platform; PReP), which would use IBM and Motorola hardware coupled with Apple software.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By 1995, Apple had $1 billion worth of unfilled orders, and investors took note of the embarrassing miscue.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

After Spindler's much publicized mistake of 1995, Apple's directors were ready to hand the leadership reins to someone new.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

However, by 1996 Apple executives were worried that the clones were cannibalizing sales of their own high-end computers, where profit margins were highest.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 1996, Spindler was replaced by Gil Amelio as CEO. Hired for his reputation as a corporate rehabilitator, Amelio made deep changes, including extensive layoffs and cost-cutting.

Only weeks away from bankruptcy, Apple's board decided NeXTSTEP was a better choice for its next operating system and purchased NeXT in late 1996 for $429 million, bringing back Apple co-founder Steve Jobs.

The NeXT acquisition was finalized on February 9, 1997, and the board brought Jobs back to Apple as an advisor.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Fortune magazine offered its analysis, referring to Apple in its March 3, 1997 issue as "Silicon Valley's paragon of dysfunctional management."

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Jobs convinced the board to make him the interim CEO in July 1997.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On July 9, 1997, Jobs staged a boardroom coup that resulted in Amelio's resignation after overseeing a three-year record-low stock price and crippling financial losses.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Jobs also ended the Mac clone deals and in September 1997, purchased the largest clone maker, Power Computing.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

November 1997 marked the launch of the Apple Store which was an application sever conceived and designed when Apple bought out NeXT.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On November 10, 1997, Apple introduced the Apple Store website, which was tied to a new build-to-order manufacturing that had been successfully used by PC manufacturer Dell.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

During the 1997 Macworld Expo, Jobs announced Apple was joining hands with Microsoft to create new versions of Microsoft for the Macintosh.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

LC CCall Number: HD9696.C64 A8633 1997 Catalog Record: 97014371 Publisher's Description Publisher-supplied Biographical Information Sample Text

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On May 6, 1998, Apple introduced a new all-in-one computer reminiscent of the original Macintosh: the iMac.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 1998, Apple purchased Macromedia’s Key Grip Software Project, thus expanding its video editing market.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Apple acquired of Macromedia's Key Grip digital video editing software project which was renamed Final Cut Pro when it was launched on the retail market in April 1999.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

A little more than a year later on July 21, 1999, Apple introduced the iBook, a laptop for consumers.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The development of Key Grip also led to Apple's release of the consumer video-editing product iMovie in October 1999.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 1999, sales grew a modest 3.2 percent, but the newfound health of the company was evident in a 94 percent gain in net income, as Apple's profits swelled to $601 million.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Next, Apple successfully acquired the German company Astarte in April 2000, which had developed the DVD authoring software DVDirector, which Apple would sell as the professional-oriented DVD Studio Pro software product, and used the same technology to create iDVD for the consumer market.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Jobs became an interim CEO, or iCEO as he called himself (Jobs was not officially the CEO until 2000). Jobs decided to make some changes around Apple.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2000, Apple purchased the SoundJam MP audio player software from Casady & Greene.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

May 2001 marked the beginning of a new era for Apple.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In May 2001 the company opened its first two Apple Store retail locations in Virginia and California, offering an improved presentation of the company's products.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On October 23, 2001, Apple debuted the iPod portable digital audio player.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The product, which was first sold on November 10, 2001, was phenomenally successful with over 100 million units sold within six years.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2001 Apple introduced iTunes, a computer program for playing music and for converting music to the compact MP3 digital format commonly used in computers and other digital devices.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The system 7 was behind giving colour to the Macintosh OS and was used until 2001 when OS X was released.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Brookfield, CT: Twenty-First Century Books, 2001.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

2001 would be a pivotal year for the Apple with the company making three announcements that would change the course of the company.

A 10 GB model was introduced in mid-2002, followed by the iPod Mini, iPod Shuffle, and iPod Nano, together representing a massive new source of revenue for the company.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2002, Apple purchased Nothing Real for their advanced digital compositing application Shake, as well as Emagic for the music productivity application Logic.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

"Everybody Wants a Piece of the iPod," America's Intelligence Wire, October 27, 2003.

2003 was the year that the iTunes store was launched with over 2 million downloads in the first 2 weeks.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2003 Apple began selling downloadable copies of major record company songs in MP3 format over the Internet.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2003, Apple's iTunes Store was introduced.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The first European Apple retail store opened in London in November 2004.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

It wasn’t long before the iMac G4 was completely disconnected and the replaced with the iMac G5 in the early summer of 2004.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

That in 2005 Apple was looking at a clear revenue of $290 million or $3.24 billion in sales.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

To begin with, Apple’s retail stores were only situated in the U.S but late 2005 saw the opening of an Apple retail store in Tokyo, Japan.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Since 2005 Apple has seen a significant increase in not only its stock price but its profits.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On January 10, 2006, the new MacBook Pro and iMac became the first Apple computers to use Intel's Core Duo CPU. By August 7, 2006, Apple made the transition to Intel chips for the entire Mac product line—over one year sooner than announced.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

When Apple surpassed Dell's market cap in January 2006, Jobs sent an email to Apple employees saying Dell's CEO Michael Dell should eat his words.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2006 an Apple Store in Sapporo opened its doors to the public.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By 2006 more than one billion songs and videos had been sold through Apple’s Web site.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

30 Years of Apple: Assessing Apple's Impact (Macworld, 2006) http://www.macworld.com/article/1050153/30impact.html

Apple also introduced Boot Camp in 2006 to help users install Windows XP or Windows Vista on their Intel Macs alongside Mac OS X.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The iPhone was announced at the Macworld Expo on January 9, 2007.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In an article posted on Apple's website on February 6, 2007, Jobs wrote that Apple would be willing to sell music on the iTunes Store without digital rights management (DRM) , thereby allowing tracks to be played on third-party players, if record labels would agree to drop the technology.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By then, the company had established itself as an industry leader and in 2007 even dropped the word computer from its corporate name.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The iPhones first version became available in 2007 but only in a few markets.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In 2007 Apple introduced the touch-screen iPhone, a cellular telephone with capabilities for playing MP3s and videos and for accessing the Internet.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

7 Farivar, Cyrus. "30 Years of Apple: Assessing Apple's Impact" Retrieved February 27, 2008, from Macworld.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The iTunes Store quickly became the market leader in online music services, with over five billion downloads by June 19, 2008.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In July 2008, Apple launched the App Store to sell third-party applications for the iPhone and iPod Touch.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By October 2008, Apple was the third-largest mobile handset supplier in the world due to the popularity of the iPhone.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Other record labels eventually followed suit and Apple published a press release in January 2009 to announce that all songs on the iTunes Store are available without their FairPlay DRM.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On January 14, 2009, Jobs announced in an internal memo that he would be taking a six-month medical leave of absence from Apple until the end of June 2009 and would spend the time focusing on his health.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Later that year on April 3, 2010, the iPad was launched in the US. It sold more than 300,000 units on its first day, and 500,000 by the end of the first week.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In June 2010, Apple released the iPhone 4, which introduced video calling using FaceTime, multitasking, and a new uninsulated stainless steel design that acted as the phone's antenna.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

2010 saw the opening of the Covert Garden Apple Store which is the largest in the world today.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The iPad was announced just 3 years later in 2010.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On January 17, 2011, Jobs announced in an internal Apple memo that he would take another medical leave of absence for an indefinite period to allow him to focus on his health.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

June 2011 saw the release of the iCloud which came to replace the Mobile me service.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On August 24, 2011, Jobs resigned his position as CEO of Apple.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On October 5, 2011, Steve Jobs died, marking the end of an era for Apple.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Apple in 2011 introduced iCloud, a cloud computing service in which a user’s applications, photographs, documents, calendars, and recently purchased music would be stored in iCloud and automatically updated in the user’s other devices.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The first major product announcement by Apple following Jobs's passing occurred on January 19, 2012, when Apple's Phil Schiller introduced iBook's Textbooks for iOS and iBook Author for Mac OS X in New York City.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On August 24, 2012, a US jury ruled that Samsung should pay Apple $1.05 billion (£665m) in damages in an intellectual property lawsuit.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On November 10, 2012, Apple confirmed a global settlement that dismissed all existing lawsuits between Apple and HTC up to that date, in favor of a ten-year license agreement for current and future patents between the two companies.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

During a press event on September 9, 2014, Apple introduced a smartwatch, the Apple Watch.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In January 2016, it was announced that one billion Apple devices were in active use worldwide.

On June 6, 2016, Fortune released Fortune 500, their list of companies ranked on revenue generation.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In June 2017, Apple announced the HomePod, its smart speaker aimed to compete against Sonos, Google Home, and Amazon Echo.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Also in June 2017, Apple appointed Jamie Erlicht and Zack Van Amburg to head the newly formed worldwide video unit.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In November 2017, Apple announced it was branching out into original scripted programming: a drama series starring Jennifer Aniston and Reese Witherspoon, and a reboot of the anthology series Amazing Stories with Steven Spielberg.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In June 2018, Apple signed the Writers Guild of America's minimum basic agreement and Oprah Winfrey to a multi-year content partnership.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

By then, the company had established itself as an industry leader and in 2007 even dropped the word computer from its corporate name. Its value was estimated at $1 trillion in August 2018, with a revenue surpassing that of $150 billion per annum.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

The purchase was approved by the European Union in September 2018.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

Xerox granted Apple engineers three days of access to the PARC facilities in return for the option to buy 100,000 shares (5.6 million split-adjusted shares as of March 30, 2019) of Apple at the pre-IPO price of $10 a share.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

During its annual WWDC keynote speech on June 22, 2020, Apple announced it would move away from Intel processors, and the Mac would transition to processors developed in-house.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

On August 19, 2020, Apple's share price briefly topped $467.77, making Apple the first US company with a market capitalization of $2 trillion.

The Macintosh would eventually ship for US$2,495 (equivalent to $6,215 in 2020), a price panned by critics in light of its slow performance.

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)

In the years ahead, the company's well-established ability to develop singular products for the digital marketplace promised to deliver impressive growth and excite the interests of consumers worldwide. It went on sale soon after debut for US$666.66 (equivalent to $3,032 in 2020). Wozniak later said he was unaware of the coincidental mark of the beast in the number 666, and that he came up with the price because he liked "repeating digits".

![](https://static.zippia.com/ui-router/images/timeline-arrow-down.svg)
![Company Founded](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

## Apple Footer

- 1. Available for Qualified Purchasers only. Qualified Purchasers purchasing an eligible Mac/iPad (“Eligible Product”) with eligible AirPods/accessory (“Promotion Product”) from a Qualifying Location through September 30, 2025 will receive Promotion Savings (up to $199, not to exceed the price of the Promotion Product). Customers will be charged for all items in their cart, including the Promotion Product. Only one Promotion Product per Eligible Product per Qualified Purchaser. Offer subject to availability. While supplies last. Additional restrictions apply. View full offer terms [here](/us-edu/shop/back-to-school/terms-conditions).
- 2. Hearing Aid and Hearing Test: The Hearing Aid feature has received FDA authorization. The Hearing Test and Hearing Aid features are supported on AirPods Pro 2 with the latest firmware paired with a compatible iPhone or iPad with iOS 18 or iPadOS 18 and later and are intended for people 18 years old or older. The Hearing Aid feature is also supported on a compatible Mac with macOS Sequoia and later. It is intended for people with perceived mild to moderate hearing loss.
    
    
  Hearing Protection: The Hearing Protection feature works with AirPods Pro 2 with the latest firmware when paired with a compatible iPhone, iPad, or Mac with iOS 18, iPadOS 18, or macOS Sequoia and later. Feature is only available in the U.S. and Canada. See [support.apple.com/120850](https://support.apple.com/120850) for total attenuation and more information. The Hearing Protection feature is not suitable for protection against extremely loud impulse sounds, such as gunfire, fireworks, or jackhammers, or against sustained sounds louder than 110 dBA.
- 3. Trade‑in values will vary based on the condition, year, and configuration of your eligible trade‑in device. Not all devices are eligible for credit. You must be at least the age of majority to be eligible to trade in for credit or for an Apple Gift Card. Trade‑in value may be applied toward qualifying new device purchase, or added to an Apple Gift Card. Actual value awarded is based on receipt of a qualifying device matching the description provided when estimate was made. Sales tax may be assessed on full value of a new device purchase. In‑store trade‑in requires presentation of a valid photo ID (local law may require saving this information). Offer may not be available in all stores, and may vary between in‑store and online trade‑in. Some stores may have additional requirements. Apple or its trade‑in partners reserve the right to refuse, cancel, or limit quantity of any trade‑in transaction for any reason. More details are available from Apple’s trade-in partner for trade‑in and recycling of eligible devices. Restrictions and limitations may apply.
- To access and use all Apple Card features and products available only to Apple Card users, you must add Apple Card to Wallet on an iPhone or iPad that supports and has the latest version of iOS or iPadOS. Apple Card is subject to credit approval, available only for qualifying applicants in the United States, and issued by Goldman Sachs Bank USA, Salt Lake City Branch.
- Apple Payments Services LLC, a subsidiary of Apple Inc., is a service provider of Goldman Sachs Bank USA for Apple Card and Savings accounts. Neither Apple Inc. nor Apple Payments Services LLC is a bank.
- If you reside in the U.S. territories, please call Goldman Sachs at 877-255-5923 with questions about Apple Card.
- Learn more about how Apple Card applications are evaluated at [support.apple.com/kb/HT209218](https://support.apple.com/kb/HT209218).
- Major League Baseball trademarks and copyrights are used with permission of MLB Advanced Media, L.P. All rights reserved.
- Apple Intelligence is available in beta on all iPhone 16 models, iPhone 15 Pro, iPhone 15 Pro Max, iPad mini (A17 Pro), and iPad and Mac models with M1 and later, with Siri and device language set to the same supported language, as part of an iOS 18, iPadOS 18, and macOS Sequoia software update. Supported languages include English, French, German, Italian, Portuguese (Brazil), Spanish, Japanese, Korean, and Chinese (Simplified). More languages are coming over the course of the year, including Vietnamese. Some features may not be available in all regions or languages.
- A subscription is required for Apple Arcade, Apple Fitness+, Apple Music, and Apple TV+.
- Features are subject to change. Some features, applications, and services may not be available in all regions or all languages.
